loans.name: Teresa

texts.en:
Teresa R. C. lives in Namaacha, Mozambique, very close to the Swazi border. She was born in the capital of the country, Maputo, 42 years ago. She moved to Namaacha because she got a job there, working for TDM, the national telecommunications company. She has been working there for the last 23 years.

She is studying 10th grade at the moment and plans to continue until 12th grade, the last year before undergraduate university level. She studies by night at the local secondary school. She is single and has four children, aged 7, 10, 19 and 21. All of them go to school, the three youngest in Namaacha and the oldest one in Maputo. She needs to take care of all four children on her own.

She explains that she previously asked Kiva for a loan to start a clothes selling business, but the business did not turn out well. The main problem was that people were taking the clothes home and promising to pay at a later date but ultimately never paid, so she had to close her business. She is determined now not to make the same mistake again and wants to have a small shop. She says that people will pay or not take the items home so she will not have the same problem again.

She is not sure of what to sell yet, so she is asking for a loan just to build the stall this time. Once the stall is built, she will decide what is best for her to sell and ask for another loan. She is confident she will be able to repay without problems, since she has her fixed salary in the telecom company and has some savings.

loans.use: to build a stall to start a small shop

loans.name: Osana

texts.en: Osana, 27 years old and married with one child, lives in Benin where she makes and sells female hats and beads at her store and also bakes cakes for marriages, birthday ceremonies and more.  Both businesses enable her to support her family's basic needs. With the loan of NGN 70,000, she plans to expand her hat and beads business, which is booming. She hopes to increase her earnings in this enterprise in the long run and be able to better provide for her child 's education.  Osana says thank you to all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase materials to make more hats and beads to sell.

loans.name: Noemi

texts.es:
Noemí es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Noemí es soltera, tiene 35 años y 4 hijos, Noemí tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, verduras, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días. Además Noemí se dedica a la confección de prendas de vestir.
Noemí necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de arroz y azúcar.
Los sueños de Noemí son mejorar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Noemí is a member of the Communal Bank “Universo” (Universe). She is 35 years old, single, and has four children. Noemí has a store in her home where she sells groceries, vegetables, and meats. She engages in her business every day. In addition, Noemí spends time making clothing.

She needs a loan of 1000 PEN to invest in the purchase of rice and sugar. Noemí dreams of improving her business and seeing her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase rice & sugar

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
Delia es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Delia es casada, tiene 62 años y 4 hijos, Delia viaja a diferentes ferias D. la región en donD. compra cochinilla, pieles, carne, productos que venD. en la ciudad D. Ayacucho. En algunas oportunidades venD. frutas en la feria.
Delia necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. cochinilla.
Los sueños D. Delia son aumentar su capital y arreglar su casa.
texts.en:
Delia is a member of the Communal Bank “Universo” (Universe). She is 62 years old, married, and has four children. Delia travels to different fairs in the region to buy cochineal (an insect used to make fabric dye and food coloring), animal hides, and meat so that she can sell these products in the city of Ayacucho. On some occasions, she sells fruit at the fair.

Delia needs a loan of 1000 PEN to invest in the purchase of cochineal. She dreams of increasing her capital and remodeling her house.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cochineal (an insect used for making fabric dye and food coloring)

loans.name: Asha

texts.en: Asha I. is married and a small businesswoman. She sells cassava wholesale to customers. She purchases her goods directly from the farmers at Chanika ward in Dar es Salaam and sells to retail customers in various marketplaces for domestic and business purposes. The income generated by the business helps her to pay school fees, meet her family's daily demands and acquire business capital. She needs a loan of 700,000 TZS to boost the business.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Geofrey

texts.en: Geofrey is a 36-year-old man living in Hoima, Uganda. He is married with two children, aged 12 and 6 years. His wife is currently a student, meaning the welfare of the family is Geofrey's responsibility. He dreams of seeing his wife through her education. He is employed as a cashier for a giant hardware shop in Hoima, Uganda. He has obtaining credit from HOFOKAM and this is his third loan through which he has been able to finish his residential house and also buy a motorcycle for his business. He intends to use the loan funds to finish construction of his residential house with a water tank

loans.use: finishing construction of his residential house with a water tank system.

loans.name: Akutwala Ekiro Group Of Mityana

texts.en:
N. Rose’s affable nature has been her winning card in the twenty-seven years she has been operating her small kiosk business where she sells foods and snacks as well as other cold drinks like sodas and passion juice in Kyadondo, Mityana. Her experience in this business has taught her to value that virtue of being cordial to clientele in whatever genre of business one operates. Given the nature of her business where competition is cutthroat, this attribute has come in really handy.

The 67-year-old mother of five divulges that, on the basis of her good human relationship skills, she has been able to make commendable strides in the improvement of her family’s welfare ever since she began her business. On a weekly and monthly basis Rose says she makes 25,000 and 100,000 shillings respectively. With this amount of money, she has managed to educate all five of her children.

Rose’s future plans are to elevate her financial status through the expansion of her business. With this loan she says she wants to buy new furniture for her kiosk and also expand her operating area.

loans.use: To purchase new furniture for her kiosk especially for the clients that eat from her kiosk.

loans.name: Celina

texts.en:
Celina A. S. was born in Maputo 30 years ago. She studied until 7th grade. She is now living in Namaacha, on the Mozambican border with Swaziland. She moved here because she got a job in a nearby hotel, where she has been working for the last 9 years. She works from 7 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. and has three free days every two weeks. The money she makes at the hotel is not enough to take care of her five dependents: three children, aged 6, 9 and 11, a cousin and a niece. 

She is asking for a loan to finish the construction work at her home. She has had two other loans with Kiva, is familiar with the process and likes it. She plans to repay the loan with her salary from the hotel and live on her husband's salary during this period. Once she is done with the construction, she plans on requesting another loan to start breeding chickens.

loans.use: to buy cement, tin, zinc and sand

loans.name: Hida

texts.es:
Hida es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Hida es casada, tiene 28 años y 3 hijos, Hida viaja a los diferentes pueblos de la región en donde compra papa, producto que vende en el mercado de abastos de la ciudad de Ayacucho, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Hida necesita un préstamo de 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de papa.
Hida sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Hida is an associate of the Universe Communal Bank. Hida is married, 28 years old and has 3 children. Hida travels to the different villages of the region where she buys potatoes, a product that she sells in the supplies market of the city of Ayacucho. She performs this activity every day. Hida needs a loan of 1000 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of potatoes. Hida dreams that her children will become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy potatoes for resale

loans.name: Benjamina

texts.es:
Benjamina es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Benjamina es casada, tiene 45 años y 2 hijos, Benjamina se dedica a L. venta D. emoliente (bebida caliente con propiedades curativas) actividad que realiza todos los días por las mañanas y noches, D. manera ambulatoria en un parque.
Benjamina necesita un préstamo D. 800 soles dinero que será invertido en L. compra D. azúcar y kerosén.
Benjamina sueña con que sus hijos culminen sus estudios.
texts.en:
Benjamina is an associate of the Universe Communal Bank. Benjamina is married, 45 years of age and has 2 children. Benjamina is dedicated to the sale of emoliente (a hot beverage with curative properties), an activity that she carries out every day in the mornings and evenings, selling on foot in a park. Benjamina needs a loan of 800 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of sugar and kerosene. Benjamina dreams that her children will complete their studies.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buy sugar and kerosene

loans.name: Otoo Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Margaret is forty-one years old. She is married and has given birth to five children who are between the ages of three and sixteen. She lives with her husband and children in a mission house of a church in the community where the husband is the pastor.

Margaret is a hard-working woman. She works to help her husband to provide for the family. She is into food production business – pastries. Margaret has been producing and supplying pastries for the past six years and is experienced. She buys her raw materials – bags of flour, sugar, vegetable oil and other ingredients from nearby towns. It is her dream to see all her children climb the academic ladder to the university level. She also aspires to produce pastries on a large scale and be able to supply to more retailers.

Margaret is the leader of a five-member trust bank group called ‘O.’, probably her surname. The group is made up of mainly traders and food vendors. According to Margaret, the group members are all sincere and hard-working. The group requests the loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to buy bags of flour and other ingredients in bulk for baking

loans.name: Leah

texts.en: Leah S. M. is married and has four children, aged between 12 and 24 years old. Her business is located in Kakamega, Kenya. She has been selling cereals such as maize, beans, wheat and groundnuts for the last six years to the local people. She says that this business is profitable and the major challenge is that there are so many people in the same business in her area and so customers are spoiled by the choice. However, she works very hard to keep her business going well. She is using her loan of KES 20,000 to buy more cereals to expand her business. She hopes to enlarge her business and start supplying in bulk. She is very hardworking and focused.

loans.use: to buy maize, beans, etc.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en: Beatrice N. is an entrepreneur running a poultry business in Yombo Buza in Dar es Salaam. She raises broiler poultry for meat. The chicks are fed for only five weeks and then sold for slaughtering. She sells 600 broilers per batch. The business income generated is used to meet the family's daily demands and to raise capital for the business. She needs a loan of 700,000 TZS to buy more poultry chicks and to construct more poultry cages.

loans.use: To expand the business by buying more poultry chicks

loans.name: Dayana Maria

texts.es: LA SRA. DAYANA ES SOLTERA, SE DEDICA A LA VENTA DE COSMETICOS POR CATALOGO TIENE 3 AÑOS DE EXPERIENCIA EN LA VENTA DE LOS COSMETICOS A PESAR DE SER TAN JOVEN, ES ALGUIEN BASTANTE RESPONSABLE QUIEN ADEMAS LUEGO DE INDEPENDISARSE DE SUS PADRES TUVO QUE EMPEZAR A GANAR SU PROPIO DINERO PARA PODER ESTUDIAR FUE DIFICIL PARA ELLA REALIZAR LAS DOS ACTIVIDADES EN TIEMPO Y DINERO PERO SUPO SALIR ADELANTE Y AHORA LE VA MUY BIEN, UNO DE SUS DESEOS ES EL DE SALIR PROFESIONAL Y DEDICARSE A SU PROFESION, ELLA ACTUALMENTE NECESITA EL DINERO PARA PODER SACAR PRODUCTOS DE PROMOCION EN EL CATALOGO Y DE ESA MANERA PROVEERSE DE MAYOR MERCADERIA. ESTA MUY AGRADECIDA CON EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA CONFIANZA BRINDADA EN LA OTORGACION DEL CREDITO.
texts.en:
Señora Dayana is single and makes a living selling cosmetics from a catalog. She has three years of experience in the sale of cosmetics despite being so young. She is a very responsible person who, in addition to becoming independent from her parents, had to start earning her own money to study. It was hard for her to do both, financially and time-wise, but she figured out how to get ahead and now everything is going well for her. One of her desires is to dedicate herself to her profession. Right now, she needs money to be able to get promotional products from the catalog and in this way sell more merchandise. She is very grateful for Emprender and Kiva for trusting her with a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Shelly Hubman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy merchandise.

loans.name: Demetria

texts.es:
Demetria es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Demetria es casada, tiene 55 años y 6 hijos, Demetria vende verduras al por mayor en el mercado Nery García, actividad que realiza todos los días con la ayuda de su hija.
Demetria necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de zanahoria.
Demetria sueña con que sus hijos sean profesionales y aumentar su mercadería.
texts.en:
Demetria is an associate of the Universe Communal Bank. Demetria is married, 55 years of age and has 6 children. Demetria sells vegetables wholesale in the Nery García market, an activity which she carries out every day with the help of her daughter. Demetria needs a loan of 1500 soles, money which will be invested in the purchase of carrots. Demetria dreams that her children will become professionals and would like to increase the variety of her merchandise.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy carrots for resale

loans.name: Libia

texts.es:
Libia es socia del Banco Comunal Universo.
Libia es casada, tiene 40 años y 5 hijos, Libia  vende verduras al por mayor en el mercado Nery García, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Libia necesita un préstamo de 2500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de tomate y cebolla.
Los sueños de Libia son aumentar su negocio y que sus hijos sean profesionales.
texts.en:
Libia is an associate of the Universe Communal Bank. Libia is married, 40 years of age and has 5 children. Libia sells vegetables wholesale in the Nery Garcia market, an activity that she carries out every day. Libia needs a loan of 2500 soles, money that will be invested in the purchase of tomatos and onions. The dreams of Libya are to grow her business and that her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy tomatoes and onions for resale

loans.name: Edwin

texts.es:
Edwin se dedica a  trabaja como chofer; su esposa es pasanaquera (Pasanaco es un sistema básico de ahorro donde un grupo establecido de personas acuerdan a ahorrar un monto definido de dinero al año, a ser pagado cada mes y cada mes se sortea a la persona a quien le toca todo ese dinero, y así sucesivamente durante el periodo que dura el pasanaco) la labor de la psanaquera es asegurarse de recoger la cuota mensual de cada uno de los participantes y entregar el total recogido a la persona sorteada; por este trabajo ella recibe una comisión. Estas dos actividades constituyen las principales fuentes de ingreso mensual  con las que cubren la manutención de su familia, tienen 3  hijos con las edades de 15, 6 y 3 años. Tiene su domicilio en la  Zona de Ernesto Torrez  de la  ciudad de La Paz.
 
El préstamo lo destinará a la compra de motor y caja para su movilidad.
 
Es su primer crédito con Impro a través de Kiva.
texts.en:
Edwin works as a driver, his wife is pasanaquera (Pasanaco is a basic system of savings where an certain group of people agree to save an established amount of money in a year, to be paid every month and every month a member who will received the money is drawn, and so on during the period that the pasanaco lasts). Her job is to collect the monthly fee from each of the participants and deliver the total collected to the chosen person; for this work she receives a commission. These two activities are the main sources of their monthly income, that they use to support their family. They have 3 children, of 15, 6 and 3 years of age. They live in the area of Ernesto Torres in the city of La Paz. The loan will be used to purchase a new engine and a gearbox for his vehicle. This is his first loan from Impro through Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by MONICA URBAN, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of engine and gearbox for taxi

loans.name: God First Group

texts.en:
Agnes is thirty-five years old. She is a married woman and has given birth to four children who are all currently in school. The children are between the ages of six and nineteen. She lives with her children and husband, a cocoa merchant, in a rented apartment in their community. 

Agnes is a hard-working woman who helps her husband to provide for the family financially. She trades in foodstuffs such as plantains. She treks to nearby towns to supply them to retailers and chop bar (restaurant) operators. Agnes has been trading in plantains for ten years and has acquired rich experience in her business. She procures her goods from nearby farming communities. It is her desire to expand her business size and also be able to give all her children the best of education she can afford.

Agnes is the leader of a trust bank group called 'God First'. It is a five-member group, most of whom are into trading while others are into food vending. The group looks forward to receiving bigger amounts to expand their businesses. They are requesting the loan to procure goods in bulk to scale up their businesses.

loans.use: to buy plantains in bulk for resale

loans.name: Franklin Antonio

texts.es: Franklin Antonio tiene 33 años con 2 hijos menores de edad a su cargo. El tiene mucho tiempo de ser cliente de Fundación, su actividad es ofrecer el servicio de tricitaxi, por lo que él siempre está buscando la forma de salir adelante ya que tiene una familia que mantener, cuando el inicio este trabajo no tenía suficiente capital de trabajo, pero con la ayuda de los financiamientos ha logrado alcanzar sus objetivos. Es así que decide realizar un financiamiento destinado para la compra de  llantas, asientos, repuestos para sus triciclos. Su deseo es seguir trabajando duro para proporcionarles a sus hijos estudios.
texts.en:
Franklin Antonio is 33 years old with 2 minor children in his charge. He has been a client of Fundación for a long time. His activity is to offer tricycle-taxi services and he is always looking for ways to forge ahead, now that he has a family to maintain. When he began this work, he lacked sufficient working capital, but with the help of loans he has managed to reach his objectives. Thus he decided to request a loan destined for buying tires, seats, and replacement parts for his tricycles. His desire is to continue working hard in order to provide for his children's studies.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING TIRES, SEATS, AND PARTS FOR HIS TRICYCLE-TAXIS

loans.name: Los Cuatro Group

texts.es:
El grupo LOS CUATRO esta compuesto por 4 integrantes D. ahí D. donD. viene el nombre, las clientes se dedican a diferentes rubros uno D. estos es el comercio D. productos comestibles por menor, el comercio D. mercaderia a crediTo tales como edredones, mp3 y otros, otra D. las integrantes se dedica a la elaboracion D. reposteria elaborando masas como donas y alfajores.    

La Sra. Sandra esta casada y tiene 3 hijos que se encuentran en edad escolar, se dedica a la venta D. edredones al contado y tambien da a credito y despues lo cobra semanalmente o quincenalmente, es muy trabajadora y D. esta manera colabora con su esposo en los gastos del hogar.
 
El grupo decidio unirse D. acuerdo a la afinidad y conocimiento que tiene la una D. la otra, y ademas la confianza y solidaridad que las carateriza, estan muy agradecidas con Emprender y Kiva por la confianza brindada en la otorgacion del credito
texts.en:
The group "Los Cuatro" (The Four) is maD. up of 4 members, which is where the name came from. These individuals are in different lines of work: one of them is a retail vendor of food products, others sell merchandise on credit, such as comforters, MP3 players, and other items, and another of the members makes pastries in bulk, such as donuts and sweet sandwich cookies. Sandra is married and has 3 school-aged children. She sells comforters on a cash and credit basis. Later she collects the money weekly or bi-weekly. She is very hardworking, and in this way contributes with her husband to the household expenses. The group decided to get together because they knew each other very well and shared an affinity for each other, based on a high level of trust and solidarity. They are very grateful to Emprender and Kiva for the trust provided in the granting of this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise

loans.name: Miroslava

texts.en:
Miroslava is divorced and is a single mom raising a 3 1/2-year-old son. Miroslava lives in Belaya Tserkov. She is co-owner of a pharmacy called “Family Pharmacist” selling various types of medication, personal hygiene products and nutritional supplements. Her pharmacy has 66,000 UAH worth of inventory. Miroslava can be characterized as a smart and determined entrepreneur. She is an achiever and always tries to accomplish her goals.

Miroslava is very health conscious. She understands the importance of fresh products that are offered for sale in grocery stores. She would like to open a dairy kiosk offering fresh and quality products to her community. Miroslava is seeking a 10,000 UAH loan to buy a small vending facility next to her pharmacy and to launch this startup.

loans.use: to open a dairy vending kiosk

loans.name: Charles

texts.en: Charles V., 61 years old, is a married woman who supports her family by selling peanut butter, sandwiches and peanuts. She lives in Bless Brgy Enclaro, Binalbagan, Negros Occidental, with her husband and their ten adult children who are between 23 and 45 years old. Charles has been a member of NWTF - Project Dungganon since 1998. She has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business selling peanut butter, sandwiches and peanuts, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of 20,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). Charles is now borrowing 20,000 PHP so that she can continue selling peanut butter, sandwiches and peanuts. This will be her 19th loan from NWTF - Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 20,000 PHP (which she paid off well within its term) was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Charles aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future wellbeing by following the “Dungganon” way. About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additonal working capital

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
Claudia se dedica al comercio; tiene una librería que  es su principal fuente de ingreso con que cubre su manutención. Está casada y aún no tienen  hijos.Vive en la casa de su madre y esta ubicada en la  Zona de Rio Seco Viviendas   de la  ciudad de El Alto.
 
El préstamo lo destinará para la compra de mercadería para su librería (como ser cuadernos, lápices,gomas, etc.).
 
Es su primer crédito con Impro.
texts.en:
Claudia is dedicated to commerce; She has a bookstore that is her main source of income, with which she covers her expenses. She is married and does not yet have children. She lives in the house of her mother which is located in the Rio Seco Viviendas Zone of the city of El Alto. The loan will be used to purchase merchandise for her bookstore (such as notebooks, pencils, erasers, etc.). This is her first loan with Impro.

Translated from Spanish by Barbara (B) Brown, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise such as notebooks, pencils, erasers, etc. for her bookstore

loans.name: Tujimbere Group

texts.fr:
Jeanne B. est présidente du groupe Tujimbere et vendeuse de jus de banane dans la marche de Rugombo.  Elle a 30 ans et elle a fait ses études jusqu’en 6e année primaire.  Elle est mariée et mère de cinq enfants dont trois garçons et deux filles qui ont successivement 15 ans, 12 ans, 8 ans, 4 ans, et 18 mois.  Deux seulement sont à l’école.  Elle est en bonne sante et elle constate qu’elle n’a aucun problème dans la vie.

Etant commerçante de jus de bananes, elle a choisi de prendre le crédit de Turame parce qu’elle était dans l’incapacité de continuer son metier sans soutien financier.  Elle vient de terminer son 1e cycle de crédit de 100,000 Fbu.  Son cycle actuel est de 180,000 qui sera orienté dans l’achat de bananes.  A la question de savoir pourquoi elle a choisi Turame, elle a répondu que Turame donne un crédit sans demander des garanties matérielles comme le font les autres institutions de micro-finance.  Elle ne peut pas alors quitter Turame sans qu’elle soit financièrement indépendante. 

Pour ce qui est de son activité, elle se lève a deux heures du matin pour préparer le jus de banane qui par après est transporté dans sa petite kiosk a jus.  Elle ne rentre pas chez elle avant qu’elle n’ait termine de vendre le jus.  Normalement, elle n’a pas de difficulté de tout vendre dans une journée.  

Elle espère mener une vie heureuse soit matériellement que physiquement.  Pour ses enfants, elle va les soutenir pour étudier afin qu’ils deviennent eux aussi capable de vivre en confort.  Elle souhaite aussi ouvrir une boutique alimentaire après son second cycle de crédit avec Turame.  En conclusion, elle encourage les autres à solliciter le crédit de Turame car Turame n’exige rien avant la réception de crédit.
texts.en:
Jeanne B. is the president of the Tujimbere group and sells banana juice in the Rugombo market. She is 30 and was able to attend school through 6th grade. She is married and the mother of five children, three sons and two daughters who are 15, 12, 8, 4 and 18 months. Only two are enrolled in school. She is in good health and affirms that she has no problems in life. As a banana juice saleswoman, she chose to take out a loan from Turame because she was incapable of continuing her work with financial support. She has just finished repaying her first loan of 100,000 Fbu. Her present loan request is for 180,000 which will be used to buy bananas. Asked why she chose Turame, she replied that Turame gives loans without requiring collateral the way other microfinance institutions do. She can't therefore leave Turame until she is financially independent. As for her business, she gets up at two a.m. to prepare the banana juice which she then brings to her little juice stand. She only goes home when she has finished selling her juice. Normally, she never has difficulty selling all of it every day. She hopes to have a happy life, both physically and materially. As for her children, she wants to be able to send them to school so that they also become able to live comfortably. She hopes to open a general store after her second loan with Turame is paid off. In conclusion, she encourages others to request loans through Turame, since Turame does not require anything before it gives out loans.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: buying bananas to make banana juice for resale

loans.name: Mary Jane

texts.en:
Mary Jane G. is a married woman who supports her family by selling bread as well as buying and selling livestock. She lives in Brgy. Cabacungan, La Castellana Negros Occidental with her husband and their four children who are between 11 and 25 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2002 and has improved her living condition with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her business she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of Php 16,000.

Mary Jane is borrowing Php 19,500 so that she can continue her bread business and her livestock business. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of Php 19,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Mary Jane aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Oksana

texts.en:
Oksana is married with a teenage son. She is an entrepreneur from Berdichev. She sells second hand clothing in a small store at the local bus station. Many people who come to her home town from neighboring villages shop at her store. Oksana offers a variety of inventory at affordable prices. Currently, she has 30,000 UAH worth of inventory. Her net profit is over 10,000 UAH. 

Oksana is requesting a loan of 8,400 UAH to restock her merchandise and increase her turnover capital. Second-hand clothing items always sell well in Ukraine where many people can’t afford to buy new clothing. Oksana is hoping to continue working with this type of merchandise as this business is the main source of income for her family. One of her long-term goals is to purchase a facility for her business and open her own little second-hand clothing store in the future.

loans.use: to increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en: Mariam A. Y. is a small businesswoman who is married, with two children. She runs a business selling charcoal to customers in Vituka ward, Dar es Salaam. She purchases her goods wholesale directly from the producers and sells to retail customers. Charcoal is the main source of domestic power in developing countries due to the high cost and inefficiency of electrical power. She is requesting a loan of 700,000 TZS to buy more goods.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Tiwaa Group

texts.en:
Mercy is forty-one years old. She is a married woman and has given birth to three children who are between the ages of six and seventeen. Mercy lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in their community. Her husband is a petty trader. He trades in general goods in a shop in the community. 

Mercy is a hard-working and a trustworthy woman, a seamstress by profession. She has been sewing for fifteen years and has trained a number of apprentices who are also currently manning their own shops. Mercy buys her raw materials such as textiles and other sewing accessories, including needles, linings, thread, etc. from nearby towns. She hopes to put up her own building structure to house her family.

Mercy is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Yesu Nti’, which literally means ‘because of Jesus’. The group is made up of five members. Some are traders and others are into hairdressing. They request the loan to procure goods and raw materials in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy textiles and sewing accessories

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna A. is a 42-year old married woman who lives in Pinoy Brgy Cartagena, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by running a general store and selling school supplies.

Myrna’s husband Danilo is a school supplies vendor and he helps his wife in the business to support the family. They have three children between 17 and 24 years old, two of whom are already working and helping the family.

Myrna joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1995 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by running her store and now earns an average monthly income of Php 36,000.

Myrna is a member in good standing. Her previous loan of Php 15,000 was used to fund her general store and it had a positive impact on both the business and on the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 14th loan, Php 28,000, which she intends to use on her general store and school supplies vending businesses. Myrna is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress out of earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: G.s. Pablo Ii Group

texts.es: El grupo solidario Pablo II lo conforman Gregoria y Petrona, por lo que tienen mucho tiempo de trabajar con Fundación, pues los financiamientos han sido su mayor apoyo. Gregoria se dedica a la elaboración de repostería hace mas de 17 años que se dedica a este negocio, ha tenido ciertos beneficios porque ha logrado proporcionarle mejoras a su vivienda y su compañera Petrona se dedica a la elaboración de bordados para toallas, manteles y sabanas pues juntas han buscado la forma de salir adelante. Es así que solicitan un financiamiento destinado para capital de trabajo y así comprar utensilios y materia prima para la elaboración de repostería.  Sueñan con mantener activos sus negocios durante mucho tiempo.
texts.en:
Gregoria and Petrona make up the Pablo II Communal Bank. They have worked with Fundación for a long time. The loans have been their biggest help. Gregoria has been in the business of making pastries for over 17 years. It has had certain benefits because she was able to make improvements on her house. Her colleague, Petrona, embroiders towels, tablecloths, and sheets. Together they have looked for the way to get ahead. That is why they are asking for a loan for working capital. They will buy utensils and raw materials for making pastries. They dream of keeping their businesses active for a long time.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working capital

loans.name: Victor

texts.en:
Victor is married with a 5-year-old son. He is an entrepreneur from Tavriyskoye, in the Kherson region. He owns several greenhouses where he grows radishes, potatoes, carrots, cucumbers, cabbages and tomatoes. Victor constructed his first greenhouse 6 years ago. Hard work, determination and rich harvests have helped him expand his business. Presently, he has about 40,000 UAH invested in this business, and his income amounts to 18,000 UAH a month. 

Victor is seeking a 15,000 UAH loan to purchase polyethylene film for his greenhouses, fertilizers, seeds, pest control chemicals and a drip irrigation unit. Victor is a hard worker. He always plans spring sowing thoroughly. He has gained much experience from previous years of farming. We believe the current loan will benefit his business and help Victor improve conditions in his greenhouses thus improving the quality of grown produce and increasing its quantity.

loans.use: to purchase polyethylene film, fertilizers, seeds and a drip irrigation unit

loans.name: Susita

texts.en:
Susita Y. is a 52-year-old married woman with seven children who lives in Hda. San Antonio Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Susita has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 8 years and earns a living by buying and selling root crops. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF, to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.		

About NWTF’s Green Loan Products
Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as a charging station for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes.  The solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.   
		
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: to extend her productive hours

loans.name: Marina

texts.es:
La señora Marina vive en casa propia con su hijo menor. Quedó viuda hace casi un año vive en la zona de Alto San Pedro de la ciudad de La paz; es jubilada y percibe una renta con la cual mantiene a su familia.

El crédito que solicita es para poner en orden los documentos legales de su casa.

Es cliente de Impro desde el año 2008 y tiene un historial de pagos muy bueno, por lo que puede acceder a un nuevo crédito.
texts.en:
Marina lives in her own house with her minor child. She was widowed almost a year ago. She lives in the Alto San Pedro area of the city of La Paz. She is retired. She gets a pension, which she uses to support her family. The loan she is requesting is to be able to put the legal documents for her house in order. She has been a client of Impro since 2008. She has a very good payment history, and she is therefore able to access a new loan.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Put the legal documents for her house in order

loans.name: Nicanora

texts.en:
Nicanora A. is a 45-year-old married woman with two children who lives in Hda. Escolastica, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Nicanora has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 8 years and earns a living by running a general store. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.
		
About NWTF’s Green Loan Products
Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as a charging station for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes.  The solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.   
		
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To be use to extend productive hours

loans.name: Felitas

texts.es:
Felicitas es socia del Banco Comunal Imperio.
Felicitas es viuda, tiene 53 años y 4 hijos, Felicitas vende diversas maquinas para panaderías, mecánicas, productos que trae de Huancayo previo pedido.
Felicitas necesita un préstamo de 1050 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de motores.
Los sueños de Felicitas son tener casa propia y mejorar su negocio.
texts.en:
Felicitas is a member of the Imperio Communal Bank. Felicitas is a 53 year old widow, and she has four children. Felicitas sells various machines for bakeries and mechanics. She gets the products, which have been previously ordered, from Huancayo. Felicitas needs a loan for 1,050 PEN to buy motors. Her dreams are to have her own house and to improve her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy motors

loans.name: Cristian

texts.es:
El señor Cristian vive en casa alquilada con su mama en la zona de Villa Nuevo Potosí de la ciudad de La Paz; trabaja como auxiliar contable en una consultora, con este ingresos el mantiene a su mama.

El crédito que solicita es para aumentar el capital de la tienda de abarrotes de su mama y de esta manera ayudar a que ella pueda generar su propios ingresos.

Esta es la primera vez que solicita un crédito de Impro;  por el carácter social puede acceder a un crédito a través de Kiva.
texts.en:
Cristian lives in a rented house with his mother in the Villa Nuevo Potosí zone of the city of La Paz. He works as an accounting assistant in a consultancy. With his income he maintains his mother. The loan he solicits is intended to increase the capital of his mother's grocery store and, in this way, help her to generate her own income. This is the first time he has solicited a loan through Impro. His good social character makes him deserving of a loan from Kiva.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: SUPPLYING MORE PRODUCTS FOR HIS MOTHER'S GROCERY STORE

loans.name: Irina

texts.en:
Irina is married with two sons. She is a market entrepreneur from Berdichev. She owns a stall in one of the local marketplaces and sells prepaid cell phone cards and plans. Irina has about 10,000 UAH worth of inventory, and her net profit amounts to 4,300 UAH a month. 

Irina is requesting a loan of 4,600 UAH to purchase additional top-up and prepaid phone cards. More and more Ukrainians can afford cell phones today which results in a growing demand for these related products. Irina likes working with this type of merchandise as it boasts good liquidity, providing her with stable income. This business is the main source of income for the family. Irina is hoping to continue expanding her business in the future and to open additional vending locations in her home town.

loans.use: to increase her turnover capital

loans.name: Florenda

texts.en:
Florenda Bumban is a 64-year-old married woman with seven children who lives in Brgy Mabini, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Florenda has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 8 years and earns a living by buying and selling root crops. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.

Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as a charging station for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes.  The solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly, renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.   
		
About NWTF:
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon — a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Solar Lantern

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Emprendedoras Group

texts.es:
LA SEÑORA ANA ES PORTERA DE UN COLEGIO Y  VIVE EN EL COLEGIO EN  DOS CUARTITOS QUE LE PRESTARON PARA QUE ELLA Y SUS TRES HIJITAS NO TENGAN QUE SUFRIR YA QUE SU ESPOSO SE ALEJO DE ELLAS PERO DOÑA ANA SALIO ADELANTE POR SUS HIJITAS ELLA VENDE DULCES EN EL COLEGIO Y HACE RELLENOS DE PAPA ,ESTOS ENTREGA A LOS COLEGIOS Y A OTRAS SEÑORAS PERO NO SOLO SE DEDICA A ESTOS  TAMBIEN SABE DE CARPINTERIA , CUANDO LE FALTA DINERO LE AYUDA A SU HERMANO ,EL LE DA LA MITAD DE LO QUE GANA Y ASI ES COMO DOÑA ANA DIA A DIA SE GANA LA VIDA LUCHANDO POR ELLA Y POR SUS HIJAS CON EL DINERO DEL CREDITO COMPRARA DULCES, JUGOS, ETC PARA SURTIR SU KIOSKO.

LA SEÑORA MARIA VIVE EN CASA PROPIA LA CUAL LE COSTO COMPRAR PORQUE NO TENIA MUCHOS INGRESOS ELLA TIEN SU TIENDITA DE BARRIO QUE ESTA EN SU DOMICILIO, ULTIMAMENTE A LA SRA. MARIA NO LE FUE MUY BIEN POR ESO SU TIENDITA ESTA UN POCO VACIA PERO CON LA OPORTUNIDAD QUE EMPRENDER Y KIVA LE DIERON COMPRARA MAS PRODUCTOS PARA SU TIENDITA ,ASI ELLA TENDRA MAS INGRESOS PARA ELLA Y PARA SU HIJITA QUE ESTA ESTUDIANDO.

LA SEÑORA ANA Y MARIA DAN GRACIAS A EMPRENDER Y KIVA POR LA OPORTUNIDAD QUE LES BRINDAN.
texts.en:
Señora Ana is a caretaker at a school and lives at the school in two little rooms which they lend her, so that she and her three daughters do not have to suffer since her husband left them. But Doña Ana has overcome difficulties for the sake of her daughters. She sells sweets in the school, and she makes stuffed potatoes, which she delivers to schools and to other women. But she doesn't just do these things. She also knows carpentry. When she lacks money, she helps her brother, and he gives her half of what she earns. This is how Doña Ana, day after day, earns a living, struggling for herself and for daughters. With the money from the loan, she will buy sweets, juices, etc., to stock her kiosk. Señora Maria lives in her own house, which she struggled to buy, since she did not have much income. She has a little neighborhood store in her house. Lately her business has not been going well, because her little store is a bit empty, but with the opportunity that Emprender and Kiva are offering her, she will buy more products for her little store, and thus she will have more income for herself and her little daughter, who is a student. Señora Ana and Señora Maria give thanks to Emprender and to Kiva for the opportunities that they offer.

Translated from Spanish by Pam McMurry, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy merchandise

loans.name: Faustina

texts.es:
Faustina es socia del Banco Comunal Imperio.
Faustina es casada, tiene 37 años y 3 hijos, Faustina tiene una ferretería en un local alquilado, actividad que realiza todos los días, los domingos viaja a la feria con los mismos productos.
Faustina necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de fierros.
Faustina sueña con ampliar su negocio y tener un local propio.
texts.en:
Faustina is a member of the Imperio Communal Bank. Faustina is 37, married, and has three children. Faustina sells hardware in a rented location. She works at this business everyday. On Sundays she travels to the fair with these products. Faustina needs a loan for 2,100 PEN to buy tools. Faustina dreams of expanding her business and having her own place.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tools

loans.name: Shem

texts.en:
Determined and hardworking, M. Shem is vibrant-sounding in terms of his business and agricultural enterprises in Murumba village. He deals in poultry farming, supplying trays of eggs to hotels and shop vendors and also owns a banana plantation. All that generates income for his family.

Shem’s main drawback has been lack of funding to purchase feeds for his poultry and mulches for his plantations which has reduced his yields. Therefore this loan will help him improve his yields in terms of milk, eggs and bananas thus enabling him to meet his customers’ high demand. It will also increase his sales revenue, hence making him more able to meet his family’s requirements in terms of his children’s tuition fees and other needs and enable him to live a more self-sustaining life.

loans.use: To buy more poultry feeds and mulches

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en: Teresita C. is a 56-year-old married woman with three children who lives in Hda. Escolastica, Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Teresita has been a member of NWTF - Project Dungganon for 10 years now, and earns a living by running a ready-to-wear clothing business. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a 3,100 Philippine pesos (PHP) loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours and, at the same time, cut fuel costs and save money in the long run. About NWTF’s Green Loan Products Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation believes that the key to poverty alleviation for the poorest is to provide services beyond just credit. To that end, NWTF offers green energy products designed to save money for its clients. In a partnership with SunTransfer and Arc Finance, NWTF distributes solar-powered lanterns that also function as charging stations for mobile phones. These families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes. The solar lantern offers a free environmentally friendly renewable source of energy that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs. About NWTF In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Solar Lantern

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Maylen

texts.en:
Maylen P. is a 23-year old married mother of 1 child who lives in Hda Escolastica Cadiz City, Negros Occidental. Maylen has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon for 2 years now and earns a living by running a food vending business. She is purchasing a solar lantern with a PHP 3,100 loan from NWTF to extend her productive hours, while at the same time cut fuel costs and save money in the long run.

Since many families normally use kerosene lamps to light their homes, the solar lantern offers a free, environment-friendly renewable source of energy, that allows them to reduce their monthly fuel costs.

They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: To purchase a solar lantern

loans.name: Halima

texts.en: Halima A. is a married businesswoman. She runs a food shop in Makangarawe ward, Dar es Salaam selling varieties of crop product goods including wheat flour, maize flour, beans, cooking oil and sugar. She purchases the goods from the food market and from suppliers. The income from the business helps her meet her family's daily demands and provides capital for the business. She needs a loan of 1,500,000 TZS to boost the business.

loans.use: to buy more goods

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma V. is a married woman who lives in Bool, Cartagena, Sipalay City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by selling fish. Alma’s husband Jaime, is a tricycle driver, and they have 5 children who are between 1 and 11 years old. Three of their children are currently going to school and also help in the business as part of their daily chores.

Alma joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in fish vending. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 12,000 from her business activities.

Alma is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 40,000 was used to fund the operations of her fish vending business, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 13th cycle loan in the amount of PHP 40,000, which she intends to also use for her fish vending business. Alma is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, such as providing them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

payments.comment: Over-reported by partner.  Reduced to local price.

loans.name: Norma Esperanza

texts.es:
Norma es socia del Banco Comunal Imperio.
Norma es soltera, tiene 43 años y 3 hijos, Norma se dedica a la elaboración de pasteles variados, actividad que realiza en su casa, sus ventas los realiza a los colegios y tiendas a donde reparte.
Norma necesita un préstamo de 2100 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar y harina.
Los sueños de Norma son tener capital propio y una pastelería.
texts.en:
Norma is a member of the Imperio Communal Bank. Norma is 43, single, and has three children. Norma makes various cakes in her house. She sells and delivers the cakes to schools and stores. Norma needs a loan for 2,100 PEN to buy sugar and flour. Norma’s dreams are to have her own capital and a pastry shop.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sugar and flour

loans.name: Svitlana

texts.en:
Svitlana is married with two children. She is a farmer from Vinogradovo, in the Kherson region. Svitlana owns several greenhouses and grows produce, such as cabbage, squash, peppers and cauliflower. Svitlana has been in this business for 5 years. Growing up in the mostly agricultural Kherson region, she learned many important things related to farming. This year Svitlana has invested 10,000 UAH in her business. 

Svitlana is seeking a 5,000 UAH loan to purchase a drip irrigation unit for her greenhouses, 500 meters of polyethylene film, 400 kg of nitrate fertilizer and 250 kg of ammonium saltpeter. She believes the current loan will help her improve conditions in her greenhouses thus ensuring richer harvests and a higher income.

loans.use: to purchase a drip irrigation unit, polyethylene film and pest control chemicals

loans.name: Bisa Nyame Group

texts.en:
Agatha is forty-one years old. She is a married woman and has given birth to six children, some of whom are currently in school while others work. The children are aged between three and twenty-four. Agatha lives with her children and husband, a cocoa farmer, in a rented apartment in their community. 

Agatha is a hard-working woman who uses her business proceeds to help her husband financially to cater for the family. She trades in a food item – meat. She supplies meat to food vendors in her community. Agatha has been in business for three years and wants a loan to procure her inventory in bulk. She desires to own a house to accommodate the family.

Agatha is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Bisa Nyame’, meaning, 'ask God'. It is a four-member group and it is made up of petty traders and palm oil producers. The group leader says the members are all truthful.

loans.use: buy meat in bulk

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia M. is a married woman who supports her family by running a general store and a rice retailing business. She lives in Prk Saisi Brgy Tan-awan Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental with her husband Victorian, who is 68 years old and engaged in buying and selling livestock, and their 5 children who are between 20 and 30 years old.

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2007 and has improved her living conditions with the help of loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and rice retailing businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 5,000.

Lydia is now borrowing PHP 15,500 so that she can continue her general store and rice retailing business. This will be her 6th cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 13,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Lydia aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Saida

texts.en: Saida M. is a small businesswoman who is married, with three school-aged children. She runs a business selling clothes in Kigamboni ward, Dar es Salaam. She purchases and sells a variety of clothes for men, women, girls and boys. She purchases her goods from wholesale shops and sells to retail customers. She also runs a cosmetics shop, which developed through income generated by clothing sales. She is requesting a loan of 1,000,000 TZS to buy more goods.

loans.use: To buy more goods

loans.name: Madolyn

texts.en:
Madolyn L. is a 47-year old married woman who supports her family by buying and selling rice, pig fattening and sugarcane farming. She lives in Hda. Bearin, Brgy Linao Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental with her husband who is a driver and also helps her run the business. They have 4 children who are between 12 and 21 years old, all of whom still go to school.

Madolyn has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2000 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in all of her business activities she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 15,000.

Madolyn is now borrowing PHP 20,000 to use on her business activities of rice sales, pig fattening and sugarcane farming. This will be her 23rd cycle loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Madolyn aspires to elevate her family’s living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the “Dungganon” way.  

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fertilizer and mulch for his plantations

loans.name: Dau's Group

texts.en:
Dau T. D. was born in 1958. She lives in Doai village, Viet Hung commune, Dong Anh district, Ha Noi. She is married with a son, who is a laborer. She has a store at home, where she sells fruit and beer. Her daily income is about 300,000 VND. Ms Dau has participated in SEDA's microfinancing program since 2006. She is the group leader of a 6 member group loan. In the last term, she borrowed 5,014,000 VND, which she has completely repaid. In this loan cycle, Ms Dau would like to borrow 7,630,000 VND to invest in her store.

About the other members in her group: San T. V. was born in 1949. She breeds pigs and is a carpenter. In this loan cycle, Ms San would like to borrow 7,194,000 VND in order to purchase additional wood supplies to manufacture furniture.

Gai T. N. was born in 1952. She has a child. Her family has a workshop to make wood furniture. She wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to buy wood.

Tai T. T. was born in 1953. She sells noodle soup in the morning. She wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to invest in her business.

Thuan T. K. was born in 1955. She raises cows and grows vegetables. She wants to borrow 7,194,000 VND to invest in her livestock.

Ha T. C. was born in 1962. She has two children. She wants to borrow 7,630,000 VND to breed pigs and poultry.

loans.use: invest in her store

loans.name: Jocelyn

texts.en:
Jocelyn M. is a 42-year old married woman who lives in Hda Bearin Brgy Linao Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by buying and selling coconut wine, running a cafeteria, selling barbecue and pig fattening.

Jocelyn’s husband Samuel works as a guard at a sugarcane plantation. They have 6 children who are between 6 and 23 years old, 2 of their children are currently going to school and help their parents in the business as part of their daily chores, while the rest work to help the family.

Jocelyn joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 2000 in the hope that she would be able to help her husband improve the quality of life of their family. With the help of her loans from NWTF-PD she has been able to increase their family income by engaging in multiple business activities of buying and selling coconut wine, running a cafeteria, selling barbecue and pig fattening. Now she earns an average monthly income of PHP 18,800 from her business activities.

Jocelyn is a member of good standing. Her previous loan of PHP 28,000 was used to fund operations of her various business activities, and it had a positive impact in both the business and the family’s living conditions. Now she is borrowing her 26th loan cycle in the amount of PHP 29,000, which she intends to use on all of her business concerns, in varying degrees. Jocelyn is working hard to achieve her dreams and aspirations for her family, which is to provide them with a brighter future and a more comfortable life.

About NWTF
In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: For additional working capital for her businesses

loans.name: Blessed Mary Group

texts.en:
Cecelia K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called Blessed Mary. She is 44 years old, married and has 8 children who range in age from 8 to 26 years. She also cares for two nephews and a niece. She could not continue her education through 11th grade due to poverty.
For 6 years Cecelia has been selling used clothes at the Vai Town market close to downtown Monrovia, Liberia. 
She started selling with 7,000 Liberia dollars she received from her brother, as working capital.
Cecelia sells good looking used clothing to customers and encourages them to continue buying from her.
Cecelia plans to use her 7,500 Liberian dollar portion of this 37,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy used bed spreads and used rugs. Her dream is to become an international business woman, build more houses and to educate her children to the highest level. 


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Cecelia is the one holding the sign. And Evelyn is inset at the lower right.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy used bed spreads and used rugs.

loans.name: Ubumwe Ii Group

texts.fr:
Cassilde N. est une mère âgée de 56 ans. Elle habite dans la Commune de Rugombo (Province Cibitoke).   Son mari est un vieux cultivateur ; elle vend du mazout qu’on utilise pour éclairer les ménages dans le milieu rural avec des lampes à pétrole. C’est un métier qu’elle a commence depuis une année alors qu’elle vivait de l’activité de ses champs en tant que cultivatrice.  Elle est sortie du métier lourd de cultivateur grâce au crédit de Turame.

Elle est mère de 8 enfants; 3 filles et 5 garçons dont deux sont déjà maries.  Trois d’entre eux étudient mais aussi elle prend en charge 2 autres enfants dont un orphelin de sa famille pour lesquels elle paie les frais scolaires. Elle a l’espoir que ses enfants finiront leurs études avec succès pour lui venir en aide dans son âge avance. 

Elle compte, avec le crédit Kiva, augmenter son capital et son business en achetant de grandes quantités de mazout pour augmenter ses revenus et ainsi faire face a ses dépenses régulières de ration alimentaire, frais de scolarité et autres frais d’entretien de son ménage. Du fait qu’elle donne son produit à crédit à quelques uns de ses clients, elle affirme que des fois elle fait face aux retards de paiement.  

Elle salue beaucoup l’initiative de Turame et Kiva parce qu’aucune garantie n’est exigée pour avoir son crédit contrairement aux banques et autres IMFs. 

Elle est membre du groupe Ubumwe II, qui veut dire en français « Unité » et fait son deuxième cycle avec Turame.
texts.en:
Cassilde N., 56, is a mother. She lives in the commune of Rugombo (Cibitoke Province). Her husband is an elderly farmer; she sells kerosene which is used in many rural households for kerosene lamps. This is a business that she has been in for one year, whereas she just lived from farming before that. She was able to rise above the physically demanding work of farming thanks to Turame. Cassilde is the mother of 8 children, three daughters and five sons, of whom two are already married. Three of them are students, but she is also responsible for the school fees of two other children, one of whom is an orphan from her family. She hopes that her children will be able to finish their studies successfully so that they can help her when she is old. With the Kiva loan, she is counting on adding to her working capital and her business, by buying kerosene in bulk to grow her income and thus be able to cover her day-to-day expenses for food, school fees, and other household costs. Since she sometimes sells on credit to some of her customers, she affirms that she sometimes has trouble with late payments from these customers. She is very grateful for Turame's and Kiva's initiatives since no collateral is needed in order to request a loan, contrary to banks and other microfinance institutions. She is a member of the Ubumwe II group, which means in translation "United", and she is on her second loan with Turame.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: purchase of kerosene used for lighting houses with kerosene lamps

loans.name: A-Z Group

texts.en:
Baccus T. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called A-Z. He is 25 years old, single and has a 4 year old child. He also cares for two brothers. He is a high school graduate. Baccus is running a mini cinema business at EDD field in the New Georgia community, Monrovia, Liberia. He has been doing this business for four years. He started with 10,000 Liberia dollars as a working capital that he had saved from working .
He approaches his customers in a nice manner and has got a lot of new movies to attract them.

Baccus plans to use his 9,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 44,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy a satellite dish, petroleum products for his power generator and more video discs. His goal is to build a new cinema and to import new video discs to improve his business, to educate his child and to build a house for his family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Baccus is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy a satellite dish, petroleum products for his power generator and more video discs.

loans.name: God Is With Me Group

texts.en:
Hawa B. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Is With Me. She is 47 years old, married and has 6 children who range in age from 21 to 39 years old. She also cares for two grandchildren. She did not have the opportunity to go to school due to poverty 
For 19 years Hawa has been selling pepper at the Logan Town market, Bushrod Island, Monrovia , Liberia.
She approaches customers in a nice manner and calls customers to buy her goods.
Hawa started with a cash amount of L$ 40.00 Liberian Dollars that she acquired from working with a humanitarian organization during the civil war. 
She plans to use her 7,500 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,500.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more pepper, salt and seasonings. Her goal is to improve her business, and she plans to buy land and build a house.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Hawa is the one holding the sign.

loans.use: To buy more pepper, salt and seasonings.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more palm oil to serve customers.

loans.name: In God We Trust Group

texts.en:
Dorithy K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called In God We Trust. She is 46 years old, married and has 5 children who range in age from 11 to 30 years old. Dorithy could not continue her education through 7th grade.
For 25 years Dorithy has been selling peanuts, clothes and cooked food at the Coca Cola Factory community in Paynesville, Liberia.
She sells good products at a low price to customers in order to encourage them to continue patronizing her business.
Dorithy started selling with very little cash but she has now improved. She faces the problem of a lot people selling the same goods that she sells, which makes business sometimes bad. 
She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more peanuts, clothes and ingredients to prepare food to be cooked for sale. Her goal is to grow and expand her business and to improve the living conditions of her family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Dorithy is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more peanuts, clothes and ingredients to prepare food to be cooked for sale.

loans.name: Rutabo Tweimukye Group, Kyenjojo

texts.en:
On the face of it, K. George William seems a hard-grinding businessman. The 37-year-old married father of five school-going children sweats his guts out selling agricultural produce in a small rural town called Rutabo in Kyenjojo district. He has been doing this for the last two years.

In a month, George makes close to 30,000 shillings. This is quite modest by any standards and, as such, he requires a loan that will help him buy more food supplies for his business.

George belongs to a group and they are on their 2nd loan. They insure each other in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To buy more sacks of cereals and other produce for resale.

loans.name: G.s. Nagarote Group

texts.es: Este grupo solidario compuesto por tres personas, tiene 20 créditos y es uno de los grupos que han sido muy responsables con sus cuotas. Laura vende ropa cosméticos y productos varios en su casa de habitación, realiza sus compras de contado pues siempre se preocupado por mejorar sus ingresos. La otra integrante que es patricia se dedica a la venta de mercadería en general las 3 son personas muy responsables y trabajadoras y Dolores que es la ultima integrante tiene su pequeña pulpería, ellas decidieron unirse para realizar  este financiamiento con la idea de mejorar sus negocio. ellas desean seguir con esta actividad económica.
texts.en:
This solidarity group, composed of 3 persons, has received 20 loans and has been one of the most responsible groups in repaying their loans. Laura sells clothes, cosmetics, and various products in her own home. She makes her purchases in cash and is always preoccupied about improving her income. Another member is Patricia who sells general merchandise. Dolores, the final member, has a small general store. All 3 are very responsible and hard working people. They decided to unite in order to receive this loan, with the idea of improving their businesses. They wish to continue with their current economic activities.

Translated from Spanish by Harold Sims, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: BUYING MERCHANDISE FOR THEIR STORES

loans.name: God Fearing People Group

texts.en:
James V. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called God Fearing People. He is 49 years old and single, with 6 children who range from 8 to 17 years old. He also cares for a sibling. James could not continue his education through college.

For 20 years James has been selling slippers at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells his slippers at low prices and sells slippers that customers need in order to encourage them to continue patronizing his business.

James started selling with very little cash. He plans to use his 6,000 LRD portion of this 30,000 LRD group loan to buy more slippers to improve his business. His goal is to grow and expand his business and to improve his family's living conditions. In the photo that accompanies this profile, James is the one holding the sign. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more slippers to improve his business

loans.name: Ssebuuka Wobadde Group Of Mityana

texts.en:
N. John Baptist is a cheerful 48-year-old married father with seven buoyant and enthusiastic school-going children.

John has been selling produce in Kyandando, Mityana, for the last ten years and with earnings from this fortitude-requiring business, he has managed to educate all his children. His likable nature has allured him to his clientele over these years and it is the reason why he has lasted this long.

John is looking forward to giving his business a greater boost after getting this loan. With this loan he wants to buy more produce like maize, groundnuts (peanuts) and beans. Since he began operating, John says he has been making 240,000 shillings per month.

loans.use: To buy more maize, groundnuts and beans

loans.name: Family Tree Group

texts.en:
Mohammed F., the leader of the group of five borrowers called Family Tree, is 50 years old, married and has six children who range from 2 to 21 years old. He could not continue his education through junior high school. For 25 years Mohammed has been tailoring at the Pipelines Road in Redlight, Paynesville, Liberia.
