He sews quality clothes with good designs and also gives his customers a warm smile when transacting with them in order to encourage them to continue to buy from him.

Mohammed started operating with 15,000 Liberian Dollars but now has about 25,000 as working capital. He sometimes faces problems with a breakdown of his sewing machine, which in turn slows down business for him. He plans to use his 14,000 Liberian Dollar portion of this 70,000.00 in Liberian Dollar group loan to buy more tailoring materials to serve customers. His goal is to expand his business into a clothing factory and improve the living conditions of his family.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mohammed is the one holding the sign, while Famata is inset at the lower right.

About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials to serve customers.

loans.name: Alcadio

texts.es:
El señor es casado, vive en el barrio las residentas de la ciudad de Pilar, posee todas las herramientas y comodidades necesarias para el desarrollo de su actividad.
El mismo se dedica a la fabricación de calzados de todos tipo, reparaciones en general con una antigüedad de más de 40 años, haciendo servicios a toda la comunidad.
Posee clientela formada, ya que recibe pedidos de clientes mayoristas quienes compran su fabricación en cantidad y modelos exclusivos, ademas posee clientes del vecino país Argentina.
Solicita el crédito para invertir en la compra de insumos  como cueros, clavos, pinturas para zapatos, colas, suelas y otros para su  negocio y agradece a la fundación paraguaya por los buenos servicios que le ha brindado a su emprendimiento.-
texts.en:
He is married, and he lives in the Las Residentas neighborhood in the city of Pilar. He has all of the tools and materials he needs to do his work. He makes all types of footwear and makes general repairs. He has been providing services for the community for over 40 years. He has established customers, and he gets orders from wholesale customers who buy exclusive models and in quantity. He also has customers in their neighboring country, Argentina. He is asking for a loan to buy supplies like leather, nails, shoe dyes, glue, and soles, among other things for his business. He is grateful to the Fundación Paraguaya for the good services they have given his enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy leather, nails, shoe dyes, glue, soles, and other things

loans.name: Trust Yourself Group

texts.en:
Kollie K. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called 'Trust Yourself'. He is 24 years old, single with a 5-month-old child. He is presently a 12th grade student who is fending for himself through business.

For 3 years Kollie has been running a provisions shop and a video club at the Rihab Road in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells goods that customers always want to buy in order to encourage them to continue patronizing his business.

Kollie started selling with a small working capital and now has a bigger shop where he does his business. He plans to use his 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more goods for his shop. His goal is to grow and expand his businesses and to improve the living conditions of his family.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Kollie is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for his shop.

loans.name: God's Blessing Group

texts.en:
Rebecca L. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called 'God’s Blessing'. She is 48 years old, married with 3 children ranging in age from 9 to 32 years old. She could not continue her education through 7th grade.

For 10 years Rebecca has been sewing and into pastry at the Bassa Town in Paynesville, Liberia. She sews very well for her customers and at a low cost in order to encourage them to continue patronizing her business.

Rebecca started sewing when she graduated from trade school where she studied sewing. And she was given a sewing machine on credit that she did work on and paid back.

She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more cloth and materials for sewing. Her goal is to grow her business to a larger size and to improve the living conditions of her family.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Rebecca is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more cloth and materials for sewing.

loans.name: Margeret

texts.en:
Margeret is 37 years old and married with three children. She lives in Benin with her family. She sews clothes and sells tailoring materials. With the profit from the business, she supports her husband and she also assists him with feeding the family. She has been doing very well since she joined LAPO.

Margeret hopes to expand her business by buying more tailoring materials to sell. She is requesting a loan of 30,000 nairas to purchase more tailoring materials to sell. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more tailoring materials to sell

loans.name: By God Grace Group

texts.en:
Mary F. is the leader of the group of five borrowers called 'By God Grace'. She is 31 years old, married with 2 children who are 8 and 12 years old. She herself did not have the opportunity to go to school.

For 10 years Mary has been selling general goods at the Redlight market in Paynesville, Liberia. She renders good service to her customers in order to encourage them to continue to buy from her.

Mary started selling with money gathered from her family but sometimes illness leaves her out of business. She plans to use her 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to increase her working capital. Her goal is to build a shop and live a better life along with her family.


In the photo that accompanies this profile, Mary is the one holding the sign.

About LEAP:

The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To increase her working capital.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more used shoes to sell

loans.name: Hilaria

texts.es:
La señora Hilaria Pérez vive en casa propia en la zona de Llojeta de la Ciudad de La Paz. Con sus dos hijas.
La señora Hilaria tiene un puesto de venta de abarrotes en el mercado de su zona, ingresos con los que mantiene a su familia.
El crédito solicitado es para la construcción de una cocina, para la instalación de gas domiciliario y el alcantarillado de su vivienda.
Esta es la cuarta ocasión que solicita un préstamo y el análisis socioeconómico realizado lo califica favorablemente y puede acceder  a un  crédito.
texts.en:
Hilaria Pérez lives with her two daughters in her own home in the Llojeta area of the city of La Paz. She has a stall where she sells groceries in the market in her neighborhood. She supports her family with the earnings from her stall. The loan she is requesting is for the construction of a kitchen, for the installation of a gas line and sewer system for her home. This is the fourth time she has requested a loan. A socioeconomic analysis that was completed scored her favorably, and she can receive a loan.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Cost of construction a kitchen, a gasline and sewer system for her home.

loans.name: Amadou

texts.fr:
Natif de Djenné,  Monsieur Amadou T.  est âgée de 34 ans mariée et père de 4 enfants. Il est polygame et vit avec ses épouses et leurs enfants dans le quartier  Kôkô de la ville de Koutiala (Région de Sikasso). 
Comme tous les enfants de leur famille, Amadou a fréquenté l’école  coranique, mais il n’a pas pu continuer les études, ce qui explique son très vite intérêt pour les activités génératrices de revenus en l’occurrence la couture, apprise auprès de son père. Sa notoriété est bonne, car il est bien sollicité par ses clients pour la qualité de ses services.  
Pour augmenter  son fonds de roulement, la taille de son activité et satisfaire sa clientèle, Amadou a décidé de rejoindre  l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso avec qui il est à son  premier prêt  individuel. 
Il compte acheter, des fournitures de couture   au Burkina Faso et à Bamako et effectue son activité dans la ville de Koutiala à une clientèle  constituée de femmes et d’ hommes au comptant. 
Amadou envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel de 100.000FCFA qu’il utilisera pour le remboursement de son échéance et satisfaire le besoin de sa   famille  avec le reste.
texts.en:
A native of Dienné, Mr. Amadou T. is 34 years old, married and father to four children. He is polygamous and lives with his wives and their children in the Kôkô district of the town of Koutiala (region of Sikasso). Like all the children in their family, Amadou went to Koranic school but was not able to continue with his studies. This explains his why he rapidly became interested in revenue generating activities, in his case tailoring, which he learned from his father. He has a good reputation, since he is in great demand from his customers for the quality of his services. In order to increase his working capital, his business volume and customer satisfaction, Amadou decided to join the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso, with which he is on his first individual loan. He is planning to buy sewing materials in Burkina Faso and in Bamako and he carries out his activity in the town of Koutiala for a customer base made up of women and men; he sells for cash. Amadou envisages making a monthly profit of 100,000FCFA which he will use for the repayments on his loan; the rest will be used to provide for the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of sewing materials

loans.name: Saturnino

texts.es: Saturnino tiene 45 años, casado y tiene 7 hijos, de los cuales 5 son mayores de edad y los 2 últimos aún en etapa escolar. Juntos viven en su casa propia, ubicado en un centro poblado de Ayacucho. A los 9 años, ayudaba a sus padres a vender frutas, pero cuando alcanzó la mayoría de edad emprendió un proyecto independiente, específicamente a la actividad agrícola; es por ello que en el presente y con una familia establecida, se dedica al cultivo y comercialización de Cacao y Frutas Cítricas, negocio al cual le va muy bien. A menudo recibe la ayuda su esposa e hijos, pero por lo general necesita de sus peones para realizar el trabajo de cosecha, en donde son comercializados en los centros de acopio de su comunidad. En el futuro piensa emprender el negocio en la venta de reses, para que así pueda extender su comercio y aumentar sus ingresos. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP, por el cual se compromete a cumplir de manera puntual sus respectivos pagos, además se siente satisfecho por los beneficios que recibe dentro de su grupo comunal. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la ampliación de su terreno de cultivo para que así pueda producir en grandes proporciones y de calidad total.
texts.en:
Saturnino is 45 years old, married, and has seven children. The five older ones are adults and the two younger ones attend school. They live together in their own house located in a neighbourhood of Ayacucho. When he was 9 years old, he used to help his parents sell fruit, but when he was older he learned a new trade and became a farmer. For that reason and because he now has a family, his job is growing and selling cocoa and citrus fruits. His business is doing well. His wife and children often help out, but generally he needs assistance from farm labourers to bring in the harvest. The produce is then sold in local warehouses. A future project for Saturnino is to learn about the sale of cattle so that he can expand his business and increase his income. This is his fourth loan with Kiva partner MFP, and he promises to make his repayments puncutally. He is pleased with the benefits received via the community group. With this loan he will buy more farmland so he can produce larger quantities of quality fruit.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more farmland

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To expand her business by purchasing additional sarongs

loans.name: Butiti Twimukye, Kyenjojo Group

texts.en:
Friendly and hardworking B. Grace is married and is the mother of six children. She has operated a bar business for three years, earning her a profit of 40,000 Ugandan shillings weekly. This bar is strategically located in Kibaati, Kyenjojo District, with Grace’s highly-esteemed customer care and hygiene pulling in a good number of customers.

With this loan, Grace hopes to purchase more drinks, that is: beers, soft drinks like sodas, and wines, in order to meet the increasing demand from her customers. This will fetch her more profit and motivate her to go for her dream of owning a well-established bar and also enable her to sustain her family’s needs.

Grace belongs to a group who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan because they want to access the future successfully.

loans.use: To purchase more beers, wine and sodas for her bar business

loans.name: Fatoumata

texts.fr:
Madame  Fatoumata S.  est âgée de 58 ans, mariée et mère de 6 enfants.  Elle  vit  dans une famille traditionnelle avec plusieurs  autres ménages au  quartier Darsalam de Ségou (quatrième région administrative de la république du Mali).
N’ayant pas fait l’école, issue d’une famille de commerçants, elle commença très tôt auprès de sa mère qui vendait des condiments alimentaires, des habits et ustensiles de cuisine, les activités génératrices de revenus.
Après avoir tenté plusieurs activités, elle choisit de se spécialiser dans l’achat et la vente de calebasses.   Elle  mène cette  activité  depuis  maintenant  29 ans et  jouit d’une grande clientèle et notoriété. 
Dans le dessein d’augmenter son fonds de commerce pour faire face à la demande clientèle, elle a  fait recours à   Soro Yiriwaso. Elle est en relation avec cette dernière depuis 54 mois, après 3 prêts solidaires et 3 prêts  individuels tous  bien remboursés, elle est à son 4ème prêt individuel. 
Elle compte utiliser  ce prêt pour acheter,  100 colis de calebasses. Elle s’approvisionne dans les villages environnants  Ségou.
Madame  Fatoumata S.  vend au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée exclusivement de femmes. 
Elle envisage  réaliser un bénéfice mensuel 75 000 FCFA, ce dernier lui permettra d’acheter une charrette et un réfrigérateur. 
Son ambition est  de construire une maison à usage d’habitation
texts.en:
Mrs Fatoumata S., aged 58, is married and the mother of six children. She lives in a traditional family with several other households in the Darsalam neighborhood of Ségou (fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali). Mrs Fatoumata S. did not attend school. She took very early an interest in income generating activities and, since she was born into a family of merchants, she began to work with her mother who sold food condiments, clothes and kitchen utensils. She tried several activities and finally decided to specialize in the trade of calabashes. She has been in this business for 29 years and enjoys a solid reputation among her many customers. She wanted to increase her working capital to meet her customers' demand and came to the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso. She has worked with this institution for 54 months. She was granted 3 solidarity loans and 3 individual loans, which have all been repaid on schedule. This is her fourth individual loan. She will use it to buy 100 packages of calabashes in the villages surrounding Ségou. She sells for cash and credit to a clientele made up exclusively of women. Mrs Fatoumata S. expects to earn 75,000 CFA francs a month, which she will use to buy a cart and a refrigerator. Her ambition is to build a house for residential use.

Translated from French by Robert Mouris, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy calabashes

loans.name: Positivas Group

texts.es:
El presente comité se encuentra trabajando en su tercer ciclo y todas lograron buenos resultados en los dos ciclos anteriores.
Hasta el momento muchas lograron abrir su negocio, otras pudieron mejorar con la ayuda de las asesoras, y de esa manera mantener el ingreso que cada una tiene,  en general, se sienten muy conformes de pertener a su comité ya que de una u otra forma facilita el conocimiento para el mejor desarrollo de sus actividades.
Así se puede hablar de la Sra. Antonia G. Britez, de 30 años de edad , tiene 3 hijos, los mismos se quedan  en la casa mientras ella sale a vender sus productos. 
Ella se dedica a la venta de chipa (preparado de alimidon de yuca o mandioca, Harina de maiz, queso, grasa de cerdo, leche), como no posee un puesto de venta sale en los semaforos en los buses para vender, así todos los días recorre bastante para lograr una buena venta para regresar a su casa preparar  el almuerzo  y vuelve a salir por la tarde ofrecer sus productos. 
Es una señora muy sufrida que tiene un día a día muy pesado  por que al llegar de su trabajo debe de realizar las tareas de la casa y todo lo hace para salir adelante con sus hijos ya que es madre soltera. 
Solicita el préstamo para cubrir algunos gastos y a la ves comprar las chipas para vender ya es la actividad que realiza para mantener a su familia.
texts.en:
This group is currently in their third loan cycle, and they have achieved good results from their previous loans. As of now, many women have managed to open their own businesses. Others made improvements with the help of advisors. As a result all of them have kept up their incomes. In general they feel very pleased to belong to the group, as in one way or another the group's knowledge helps each of them in their various jobs. One example from the group is 30-year old Sra. Antonia G. Britez who has three children. They stay at home while she goes out to sell her products. She sells chipa (a kind of bread made from starch obtained from yucca or cassava, maize flour, cheese, lard, and milk). As she doesn't have a stall, she goes to traffic lights and sells to bus passengers. So she covers a lot of ground each day in order to have good sales. She returns home to prepare lunch and goes out again in the afternoons to make more sales. Antonia is a long-suffering woman whose daily life is hard. When she gets home from work, she has to do the household chores and everything else that will help her family get ahead as she is a single mother. The loan will be used to cover various expenses and to buy chipa to sell as this is how she supports her family.

Translated from Spanish by Jane Agg, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients for chipa (kind of bread)

loans.name: God Come First Group

texts.en: Yassah S. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called God Come First Group. She is 61 years old, is married, and has three children whose ages range from 15 to 27 years. Yassah did not have the opportunity to go to school. In the photo, she is the one holding the sign. For fourteen years Yassah has been selling general goods and foodstuffs at the Red Light market in Paynesville, Liberia. She has good pricing and renders good service to her customers which makes them keep returning. She usually faces problems with the rainy season because, when it rains, people don’t come out to buy. Yassah started selling with money she borrowed from her family. She plans to use her 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more general goods and foodstuffs. Her goal is to build a store for her business and to improve her family’s living conditions. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more general goods and foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Yesu Nti Group

texts.en:
Mercy is forty-one years old. She is a married woman and has given birth to three children who are between the ages of six and seventeen. Mercy lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in their community. Her husband is a trader. He trades in general goods in a shop in the community. 

Mercy is a hard-working and a trustworthy woman. She is a seamstress by profession. She has been sewing for fifteen years and has trained a number of apprentices who are also currently manning their own shops. Mercy buys her raw materials such as textiles and other sewing accessories, including needles, linings, thread, etc. from nearby towns. She hopes to put up her own building structure to house her family.

Mercy is the leader of a trust bank group called ‘Yesu Nti’, which literally means ‘because of Jesus’. The group is made up of five members. Some are traders and others are into hairdressing. They request the loan to procure goods and raw materials in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To buy textiles and sewing accessories

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more general goods to sell

loans.name: Mario

texts.es:
El señor es casado, su unidad familiar esta compuesto de tres personas, en su residencia se demuestra que cuentan con todas las comodidades para el desarrollo de su actividad, el mismo es de Pilar , vive en el barrio 12 de Octubre, se dedica al comercio, con una antigüedades hace más de 5 años, posee también un cyber (negocio con computadoras disponibles con Internet) con varias maquinas disponibles y una fotocopiadora.
Solicita el crédito para invertir en la compra de algunas antigüedades para su  negocio y otras accesorios necesarios para su local.
Agradece a la fundación paraguaya por los buenos servicios que le ha brindado a su emprendimiento.-
texts.en:
Sr. Mario is married and has a family consisting of three people. In his home, he has all the amenities needed to develop his business. He and his wife Pilar live in the October 12th neighborhood.

Mario has been engaged in selling antiques for more than five years. He also owns an Internet café where he has several available computers and a photocopier.

Mario is requesting a loan to invest in the purchase of a few antiques and other needed accessories for his Internet business. He is grateful for the good service that Fundación Paraguaya has provided to his enterprise.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase antiques to sell & supplies for his Internet business

loans.name: Our God Is Able Group

texts.en: R. W. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Our God Is Able Group. He is married and has one child and also cares for two siblings. He is a high school student seeking higher education whilst doing business. In the photo, he is the one holding the sign. For ten years R. has been into tailoring at the Red Light Market in Paynesville, Liberia. He renders good service to his customers in order in order to encourage them to keep returning but sometimes he becomes ill, which makes business bad for him. R. started sewing with the small savings from his account. He plans to use his 5,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 25,000 Liberian dollar group loan to improve his business. His goal is to grow his business to a better size and improve the living conditions of his family. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To improve his business

loans.name: Tiwaa Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Comfort is fifty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to six children who are between the ages of seven and thirty-two. Some are married and currently live with their spouses. Others are, however, still in school. 

Comfort lives with her husband and the younger children in a rented apartment in the community. Her husband is a teacher by profession. Comfort is hard-working. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells 'kenkey', a local dish made of corn dough served hot with peppers and fried fish. She has been in business for four years. 

Comfort buys her raw materials – bags of maize, fish and other ingredients--from nearby communities. She desires to support all her children up to the university level.

Comfort is the leader of a six-member trust bank group called ‘Tiwaa’, the leader’s surname. The group is made up of mainly traders and food vendors. They request the loan to procure goods in bulk to expand their businesses.

loans.use: to buy bags of maize and other ingredients for 'kenkey'

loans.name: Focused Group

texts.en: Theo M. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Focused Group. He is 27 years old, is single with a 2-year-old child and also cares for a sibling. He is presently a college student and also involved in business. In the photo, Theo is the one holding the sign. For two years Theo has been selling cosmetics such as soap and body spray at the Police Academy Junction in Paynesville, Liberia. He gives his customers a discount when they comes to buy which makes them keep returning. Theo started selling with 10,000 Liberian dollars but now has more than 24,000 Liberian dollars as working capital. He faces problems with the change in prices of goods on the market and the slowdown of sales. Theo plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000.00 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more soaps, body sprays and deodorants to sell. His goal is to grow his business to a shop and live a better life along with his family. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more soaps, body sprays and deodorants to sell

loans.name: Alfoncia

texts.es:
Alfoncia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Luren.
Alfoncia es soltera, tiene 68 años y 5 hijos, Alfoncia viaja a la feria de Paras en donde vende verduras, abarrotes, y de la feria compra quesos, carne, productos que vende en los mercados de la ciudad de Ayacucho.
Alfoncia necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de azúcar, arroz, fideo.
Alfoncia sueña con mejorar su casa.
texts.en:
Alfoncia is a member of the Señor de Luren Communal Bank.

Alfoncia is a 68-year-old single mother with 5 children. She travels to the Paras open-air market to sell vegetables and other goods. At that market, she purchases meat and cheese, which she then sells at the markets of Ayacucho.

Alfoncia needs a 1,500.00 PEN loan, which will be invested in purchasing sugar, rice, and noodles. She dreams of home improvement.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sugar, rice, and noodles

loans.name: We Are Blessed #2 Group

texts.en:
Tutu L. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called We Are Blessed #2 Group. She is 29 years old, is married, and has five children. She did not have the opportunity to go school. In the photo, she is the one holding the sign.

For nine years Tutu has been selling used clothes at the Pipelines community in Paynesville, Liberia. She renders good services to her customers which makes them keep returning. She started selling with a small amount of funds borrowed from her savings club but faces problems with having insufficient capital for her business which gives her a small problem.

Tutu plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more used clothes to sell. Her goal is to expand her business and improve the living conditions of her family.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes to sell

loans.name: Magdalena

texts.es:
Magdalena es socia del Banco Comunal Señor D. Luren.
Magdalena es casada, tiene 52 años y 5 hijos, Magdalena viaja a las diferentes ferias D. la región en donD. compra animales que luego venD. en la feria D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho. Además venD. carne D. casa en casa.
Magdalena necesita un préstamo D. 1000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. ganado ovino.
Los sueños D. Magdalena son mejorar su casa y comprar un terreno para sembrar.
texts.en:
Magdalena is a member of the Señor D. Luren Communal Bank.

Magdalena is a 52-year-old married mother with 5 children. She travels to the different open air markets throughout the region to purchase animals, which she then sells at the Ayacucho market. She also sells meat from door-to-door.

Magdalena needs a 1,000.00 PEN loan, which will be invested in purchasing sheep. She dreams of home improvement and of purchasing a plot of land for growing crops.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sheep

loans.name: Mariama

texts.en:
Mariama J. is a widow with four children. She is an experienced trader who has traded for thirty years. She owns a shop along Fenton Road where she sells provisions. She is assisted by her children in the shop.

Mariama is a client with a very good credit history. She is seeking a loan in order to buy more provisions. She hopes to use the proceeds from the loan to start construction on her reserved site and to educate her children.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell

loans.name: Tamara Liseth

texts.es: Tamara es una joven de 21 años, vive junto con su mama la cual ha apoyado siempre, como muchas,  madre soltera de dos hijos el cual trabaja bastante para que no le falte la alimentación  a sus pequeños. Su negocio era la venta de comida pero como las ventas tras varios meses bajaron, decidieron  dedicarse a la venta de ropa y cosméticos. En donde ella comienza a viajar a los departamentos para abrir nueva clientela. En donde su objetivo lo logra ya que las ventas son buenas. Mantienen cosméticos y ropa de venta en la casa también, un día a la semana viaja a los departamentos para ofrecer sus productos, en donde horas muy temprana toma el bus, para poder regresar el mismo día a la capital. Sus planes es invertir en vitrinas en donde pueda exhibir su cosmético y lograr la captación de clientes nuevos.
texts.en:
Tamara is a young woman who is 21 years of age. She lives with her mother who has always supported her. Like many women, she is a single mother of two children and works hard so that they do not lack anything to eat. Tamara was in the business of selling food, but her sales have fallen in the past several months. She decided to sell clothing and cosmetics. Tamara started traveling to other departments to find new customers. She achieved her goal and was able to obtain good sales.

Tamara also maintains an inventory of cosmetics and clothing in her home. One day a week, she travels to other departments to offer her products. In the early hours, she gets on a bus and returns the same day to her home in the capital. Her plan is to invest in display cabinets so that she can exhibit her cosmetics and attract new customers.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase display cases, cosmetics, and clothing

loans.name: Rocio

texts.es: Rocío tiene 26 años de edad, es soltera, vive en una casa arrendada, ubicada en el centro poblado de Rosario, Ayacucho. Hace un tiempo decidió emprender un proyecto propio que le ayudase a mejorar su condición de vida, desde entonces se dedica a la actividad agrícola, específicamente al cultivo de Cacao y la Hoja de coca; por lo que en temporada de siembra y cosecha necesita de peones para que le puedan facilitar en un menor tiempo la recolección de sus productos. Rocío dedica todo su tiempo en su chacra desde las 7:00 AM  hasta las 6:00 PM, durante toda la semana, motivo por el cual sus ventas crecieron paulatinamente, ya que su producción son vendidos en los centros de acopio de su comunidad. En el futuro anhela comprar una casa propia, de esa manera evitará alquilar vivienda. Este es su primer crédito con MFP, en la cual espera cumplir con sus pagos, asimismo agradece a su grupo comunal por el respaldo que le brindan. Con el crédito que solicita, hará un mantenimiento a su terreno de cultivo para reforzar su siembra y asegurar una buena cosecha.
texts.en:
Rocío is a 26-year-old single woman who lives in a rented house located in the small town of Rosario, Ayacucho. She decided to start her own business a while back in order to improve her living conditions. Since then, she has been working in agriculture, namely cultivating cacao and coca leaves. During planting and harvesting season, she needs the help of farm workers. Rocío is at her small farm from 7:00 AM to 6:00 PM during the week, which is why her sales have been gradually increasing since her produce is sold at the wholesale centers in her community. In the future, she would like to purchase her own house so that she will avoid having to rent a place. This is her first loan with MFP, and she hopes to be able to fulfill her payments. She also thanks this microfinance institute for the support that it has given her. With this loan, she will provide maintenance to her fields so that she can strengthen her crops and ensure a good harvest.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Crop field maintenance

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling generic pharmaceutical products

loans.name: Madres Trabajadoras Group

texts.es:
El comité “Madres Trabajadoras”tiene  casi  3 años de formación y trabaja de forma bien organizada  con la Fundación Paraguaya , la mayoría de sus integrantes ya  realiza actividades productivas, para este ciclo se integraron 4 señoras que se interiorizando sobre las actividades todas realizan ya que ella también deseen desarrollar alguna actividad  productiva para ayudar a sus familias. 
Incluyen entre las actividades que las integrantes realizan la venta de frutas y verduras , venta de comestibles artesanales como empanadas de carne ,empanadas de pollo ,empanadas de jamón y queso.
Anhelan un futuro mejor para sus hijos es por eso que se esfuerzan el doble para facilitarles los materiales para su desarrollo y formación.
La señora Blanca P. es una de las integrantes  quien se dedica a la venta de comidas, desayuno y almuerzo.
Ella con la ayuda de su familia prepara los comestibles todos los días para ofrecer a sus familias. Cada día cuenta con un menú diferente, entre ella se puede mencionar, como los GUISOS de arroz y fideo, bifes, tortillas, empanadas, milanesa, caldos y otros.
Solicita el préstamo para la compra de ingredientes para los comestibles que ella prepara.
texts.en:
The Madres Trabajadoras (Working Mothers) Group has been around for almost three years, working in conjunction with Fundación Paraguaya. Most of its members are already involved in productive activities. During this loan cycle, 4 new members have joined, and they have been learning the ropes about business since they, too, want to develop some sort of business to help out their families. The members sell products like fruits and vegetables, and homemade food like meat, chicken, or ham and cheese empanadas.

They hope for a better future for their children, which is why they double their efforts to provide them with the tools they need for their development and upbringing.

Ms. Blanca P. is one of the group members who sells breakfast and lunch. With her family's help, she prepares meals to sell to other families every day. The menu changes daily, and some dishes include: rice or noodle stew, steak, tortillas, empanadas, breaded cutlets of meat, soups, and other meals.

She is requesting this loan in order to purchase the ingredients she needs to prepare her dishes.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase meat, bread, milk, eggs, rice and noodles

loans.name: Carmen Rosa

texts.es:
Carmen es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Luren.
Carmen es soltera, tiene 30 años y 1 hijo, Carmen tiene una fotocopiadora en un local alquilado al frente de una institución, además brinda servicios de tipeos y llamadas telefónicas.
Carmen necesita un préstamo de 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de papeles y toner.
Carmen sueña con tener casa propia y brindar una buena educación a su hijo.
texts.en:
Carmen is a member of the Señor de Luren Communal Bank.

Carmen is a 30-year-old single mother with one son. She has a photocopier in an office space in front of an educational institute. She offers copy, typing, and calling services.

Carmen needs a 1,250.00 PEN loan, which will be invested in purchasing paper and toner. She dreams of owning a house and of being able to provide her son with an education.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase paper and toner

loans.name: Women Of Success Group

texts.en: Comfort G. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Women Of Success Group. She is 27 years old, is married, and has a 4-year-old child. She also cares for a few relatives. She is presently a college student but is also involved in business. In the photo, she is the one holding the sign. For four years Comfort has been selling oil at the Omega Tower Community in Paynesville, Liberia. She gives her customers good service which makes them keep returning. Comfort started selling with a small amount of funds borrowed from her savings club. She faces problems with having inadequate capital for her business which gives her a small problem. Comfort plans to use her 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more goods to sell. Her goal is to expand her business for the benefit of her family. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more goods to sell

loans.name: Claudia

texts.es:
Claudia es socia del Banco Comunal Señor D. Luren.
Claudia es casada, tiene 57 años y 10 hijos, Claudia tiene una tienda en su casa en donD. venD. abarrotes en  general, verduras, carnes, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Claudia necesita un préstamo D. 1250 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. azúcar, arroz y cerveza.
Claudia sueña con vender mas productos.
texts.en:
Claudia is a member of the Señor D. Luren Communal Bank.

Claudia is a 57-year-old woman with ten children. She runs an in-home store in which she sells general goods, vegetables, and meats every day.

She needs a 1,250.00 PEN loan, which she will invest in purchasing sugar, rice, and beer. Claudia dreams of being able to sell more products.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sugar, rice, and beer

loans.name: Luzmila

texts.es:
Luzmila es socia del Banco Comunal Señor D. Luren.
Luzmila es viuda, tiene 64 años y 8 hijos, Luzmila venD. helados D. la región llamado Muyuchi, actividad que realiza los días sábados y domingos en el parque principal D. la ciudad D. Ayacucho.
Luzmila necesita un préstamo D. 2000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra D. azúcar, esencia y coco.
Luzmila sueña con mejorar su casa y terminar D. cancelar el terreno que compró.
texts.en:
Luzmila is a member of the Communal Bank Señor D. Luren. She is a widow, 64 years old, and has 8 children. Luzmila sells ice cream in the Muyuchi region on Saturdays and Sundays in the main park in the city of Ayacucho. Luzmila needs a loan of 2000 soles that she will use to purchase sugar, flavorings, and coconut. She dreams of improving her home, and completing a fence around the piece of land that she purchased.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase sugar, flavoring, and coconut

loans.name: Vladimir Ramon

texts.es: El señor Vladimir es un hombre dedicado al negocio, de edad de 50 años vive junto con su mama, desde hace varios años logro poner una venta de fritanga en su casa, pues para el no ha sido difícil ya que su mama le enseño a cocinar los ricos platillos, con los años logro poner un pequeño local en donde siempre vende comida. Lo que desea comprar con este préstamo es una cocina nueva ya que la que tiene le da problemas, así como sillas y mesas nuevas para dar un mejor servicio a sus clientes. Hay días en los cuales las ventas son bajas y se gana poco, pero también hay días en donde se vende todo la comida. Con este financiamiento ha logrado invertir más en sus ventas, lo que ha dejado mejores utilidades.
texts.en:
Vladimir is a businessman. He is 50 years old and lives with his mother. Several years ago he set up a business selling home cooked meals (fritanga) from his home. It was not difficult for him since his mother taught him to cook delicious meals, and over the years he was able to set up a small shop where he always sells meals. With this loan, he would like to purchase a new stove, since the one he has is giving him problems, as well as new tables and chairs to provide better service to his customers. There are days in which sales are bad and he doesn't earn much, but there are also days in which he sells all of the food. With this loan he is able to invest more in his sales, which has given him better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase a new stove, tables and plastic chairs to provide better service each day

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Selling basic necessities

loans.name: Unity For Peace Group

texts.en: Zinco M. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Unity for Peace Group. He is 28 years old, is married, and has two children whose ages range from 2 to 6 years. Zinco completed high school. In the photo, he is the one holding the sign. For seven years, Zinco has been selling at Buchanan Parking, Red Light. He sells in a friendly manner which keeps customers returning. He is involved with the sale of clothes, mostly jeans. Zinco plans to use his 6,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 30,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more jeans. His goal is to grow his business and to continue to support his children so that they can have a better future. About LEAP: The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating micro-finance institution with thirteen branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socio-economic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and puts emphasis on lending to women. Join the Team LEAP - Liberia lending team on Kiva today!

loans.use: To buy more jeans to sell

loans.name: Rosalynn

texts.es:
Rosalynn es socia del Banco Comunal Señor de Luren.
Rosalynn es soltera, tiene 28 años y vive con sus padres, Rosalynn estudia repostería y prepara postres de acuerdo a pedidos de sus clientes, además trabaja en una cebicheria junto a sus hermanos.
Rosalynn necesita un préstamo de 750 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de batidora.
Rosalynn sueña con implementar un negocio en donde venda sus productos.
texts.en:
Rosalynn is a member of the Communal Bank Señor de Luren. She is single, 28 years old, and lives with her parents. She is studying to be a pastry chef and makes custom desserts for her customers. She also works in a restaurant with her siblings. Rosalynn needs a loan of 750 soles to purchase a mixer. She dreams of setting up her own business where she can sell her products.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase a mixer

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Making and selling polenta made from corn

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es:
Nancy es socia del Banco Comunal Virgen Maria.
Nancy es conviviente, tiene 25 años y 1 hijo, Nancy tiene una tienda en un local alquilado en donde vende repuestos de carro, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Nancy necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de repuestos.
Los sueños de Nancy son tener un local propio y sacar adelante a su hijo.
texts.en:
Nancy is a member of the Communal Bank Virgen Maria. She lives with her common law husband, is 25 years old and has one child. She has a shop in a rented space where she sells car parts daily. She needs a loan of 3000 soles which she will used to purchase parts. He dreams are to have her own shop and to help her son get ahead in life.

Translated from Spanish by Michele Magrino, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase car parts

loans.name: Iron Market Group

texts.en:
Hawa T. is the leader of this group of five borrowers called Iron Market. She is 60 years old, is married, and has seven children whose ages range from 22 to 45. Hawa did not have the opportunity to go to school.

For forty years Hawa has been selling hardware for construction at the Parker Paint community in Paynesville, Liberia. She sells goods that her customers want in order to encourage them to continue buying from her.

Hawa started selling with a small amount of funds right after the war and now has more capital. However, she faces problems with others in the market selling the same goods that she sells which makes business slow for her.

Hawa plans to use her 4,000 Liberian dollar portion of this 20,000 Liberian dollar group loan to buy more hardware to sell. Her goal is to expand her business and improve her family’s living conditions.



In the photo that accompanies this profile, Hawa is the one holding the sign.  Bendu T. is inset at the lower right.

loans.use: To buy more hardware to sell

loans.name: Graciela

texts.es:
Graciela es socia del Banco Comunal Virgen Maria.
Graciela es casada, tiene 54 años y 2 hijos, Graciela viaja a las diferentes ferias de la región en donde compra animales, Graciela vende la carne de casa en casa, actividad que realiza todos los días.
Graciela necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de ganado ovino y porcino.
Los sueños de Graciela son que sus hijos sean profesionales y aumentar su negocio.
texts.en:
Graciela is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen Maria” (Virgen Mary). She is 54 years old, married, and has two children. Graciela travels to different fairs in the region to buy animals. She sells the meat door to door and engages in this business every day.

Graciela needs a loan of 1500 PEN to invest in the purchase of sheep and pigs. She dreams of increasing her business and seeing her children become professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase sheep & pigs

loans.name: Vandi

texts.en:
Vandi M. is a footballer and also a trader who sells phone cards, e-vouchers, drinks and pure water at Kpadahun Road by the Bo clock tower.

He is married to a hair dresser with a child who is in primary school.  He buys the items wholesale and supplies to his customers within Bo and surrounding areas.

He is always at his business place after his morning exercise and is so committed to his business. He is seeking a loan so that he can purchase large quantities of stock in order to increase his profit margin and then use the proceeds from the loan to acquire a piece of land and take proper care of his home.

loans.use: To buy phone cards and drinks

loans.name: Rosalpina

texts.es: Rosa Alpina tiene 45 años, su actividad económica es una pulpería, en donde ofrece los diferentes productos que sus clientes le solicitan, por lo que tiene muchos clientes ya que en su cuadra tiene mucha popularidad, pues además de ofrecer un excelente servicio también ofrece un singular carisma. Ella inicio este negocio porque anteriormente ofrecía frijoles y tortillas, pero con el paso del tiempo fue aumentando sus ganancias y ella compraba diferentes productos, fue así que llego a tener lo que es su actividad ahora. Esta solicitando este financiamiento para capital de trabajo que será destinado para la compra de refrescos naturales, pan, galletas, detergentes. Ella sueña con mantener su negocio.
texts.en:
Rosalpina is 45 years old and operates a grocery store where she offers different products that her customers request. Her store is very popular and has many customers from her block as a result of the excellent service that she provides and her unique charisma. Prior to starting this business, Rosalpina sold beans and tortillas. However, over the course of time, she was generating more profits and started buying different products to build up the business she has now.

Rosalpina is requesting this loan as operating capital to buy natural beverages, bread, cookies, and detergents. She dreams of maintaining her business.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to buy more merchandise

loans.name: Rosa Rufina

texts.es:
Rosa es socia del Banco Comunal Virgen Maria.
Rosa es casada, tiene 68 años y 6 hijos, Docente Cesante, Rosa tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende bebidas, actividad que realiza con la ayuda de su esposo.
Rosa necesita un préstamo de 3000 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cerveza y gaseosa.
Rosa sueña con tener estabilidad económica y ayudar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Rosa is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen Maria” (Virgen Mary). She is 68 years old, married, and has six children. Rosa is a retired schoolteacher. She now has a store in her home where she sells beverages with the help of her husband.

Rosa needs a loan of 3000 PEN to invest in the purchase of beer and sodas. She dreams of having financial stability and helping her children.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase beer & sodas

loans.name: Olga

texts.es:
Olga es socia del Banco Comunal Virgen Maria.
Olga es casada, tiene 37 años y 3 hijos, vive en el Distrito de Acosvinchos, Olga se dedica a la compra de cereales que luego vende en la ciudad de Ayacucho, además Olga tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su casa.
Olga necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de cereales.
Olga sueña con tener una ferretería y educar a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Olga is a member of the Communal Bank “Virgen Maria” (Virgen Mary). She is 37 years old, married, has three children, and lives in the District of Acosvinchos. Olga buys grain to sell later in the city of Ayacucho. She also has a grocery store in her home.

Olga needs a loan of 1500 PEN to invest in the purchase of grain. She dreams of opening a hardware store and providing her children with an education.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase grain

loans.name: Maribel

texts.es: Maribel tiene 31 años, madre de dos hijos, por lo que viven juntos en casa de sus padres. Desde que era niña, se dedica a las labores agrícolas, paralelamente a esto trabajo, posee ovejas en su establo. Diariamente su actividad consiste en cuidar sus cultivos de maíz y papa, por lo que ahora se encuentra en la espera de la cosecha de papa que hace algunos meses sembró. Una vez llegada la recolección de su producto, piensa comercializarlos directamente al mercado mayorista, para recibir los resultados de su arduo trabajo. Su deseo es tener varias extensiones de terreno, además aquellos terrenos que conserva, poder aplicarle abono y fertilizantes para preparar la tierra antes de sembrar. Este es su cuarto crédito con MFP, por lo que asegura ser responsable con sus pagos, asegura además que el aporte que recibirá le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. El crédito que solicita, lo invertirá en la compra de sacos de abono para continuar sembrando maíz.
texts.en:
Maribel is 31 years old and the mother of two children. She lives with them in her parents’ house. Since she was a girl, Maribel has been engaged in farm work. In addition, she has a stable where she raises sheep. Her daily schedule consists of looking after her crops of corn and potatoes. She is now waiting for her potato crop that she planted a few months ago. Once it is time to harvest, Maribel plans to sell the produce directly to the wholesale market so that she can get paid for her hard work. Her wish is to have several tracts of land. In order to maintain the land she has now, she wants to apply compost and fertilizers to prepare it before planting another crop.

This is her fourth loan with MFP. Maribel promises to be responsible with her payments and assures us that the funds will be useful in advancing her business. The loan she requested will be used to purchase sacks of compost so that she can continue planting corn.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase compost

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of basic necessities

loans.name: Hope To God Group

texts.en:
Zainab C., pictured on the right, is the leader of this group called “Hope To God Group”. The 35-year-old woman lives in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone, with her husband and two children. Zainab has been a businesswoman for many years now. She sells dishes. 

Zainab has requested a loan of SLL 500,000 from Kiva field partner SMT, in order to expand her business by buying dishes at wholesale to add to her current stock. This is the first loan members of the “Hope To God Group” have requested from SMT/Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Buy dishes at wholesale to add to her current ones

loans.name: No Mistake Group

texts.en:
Zainab K., pictured on the right, is the leader of this group called “No Mistake group”. The 38-year-old woman lives in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone, with her husband and two children. Her children attend primary school. Zainab has been a businesswoman for many years now. She sells groundnuts/peanuts. 

Zainab has requested a loan of SLL 500,000 from Kiva field partner SMT, in order to expand her business by buying bags of groundnuts to add to her stock. This is the first loan members of the “No Mistake group” have requested from SMT/Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy bags of groundnuts

loans.name: Camera Group

texts.en:
Ya Rugie K. who is pictured second from right is the leader of this group called “Camera group”. The 42-year-old woman lives in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone, with her husband and two children. One of her children is in secondary school and the other is not of school going age. Ya Rugie has been a businesswoman for 11 years now. She sells bananas, cassavas, pepper, salt, etc.  

Ya Rugie has requested a loan of SLL 500,000 from Kiva field partner SMT in order to expand her business by buying the above-mentioned items at wholesale to add to her stock. This is the first loan members of the “Camera group” have requested from SMT/Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy bananas, cassavas, pepper, salt, etc. at wholesale

loans.name: Sorbeh Group

texts.en:
Fatu K., on the right in the photo, is the leader of this group. She is a 48-year-old woman who lives in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone, with her husband and one child. Fatu has been selling groundnuts/peanuts for twenty years. 

She has requested a loan of SLL 800,000 from SMT, a Kiva field partner, to purchase bags of ground-nuts to add to her current stock. This is the first loan Fatu and her group members have requested from SMT/Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy groundnuts wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Faithful Group

texts.en:
Elizabeth F., who is on the right in the photo, is the leader of this group called “Faithful.” She is a small-businesswoman. She sells bottled water, palm-oil (the most popular cooking oil), vegetable oil, salt, etc. She is 40 years old and is married to a pastor. They have four children. Two of her children are in secondary school and two are in primary school. Like other mothers, she wants to give them a proper education and a bright future. She thanks God for her business because it helps provide for the increasing needs in her household. It is also a big help in sustaining her children’s education. 

Elizabeth F. has applied for a loan of SLL 500,000 to expand her business by buying food items in wholesale to add to her current ones.

Other members of the group will also use their share of the loan to expand their businesses. For example, Solomon S. is visually impaired, but unlike the vast majority of visually impaired in Sierra Leone who depends on begging in the streets for alms, Solomon choose to engage in a business. He produces and sells soap. He depends heavily on his “soda soap” business for his survival. 

(Attached to this photo is a snapshot of Solomon S., who was not able to be present for the group photo).

loans.use: Buy palm-oil, vegetable oil, salt, etc. to add to her business inventory

loans.name: Antonia

texts.es: Antonia tiene 48 años, madre de 3 hijos y juntos viven en su casa propia. Desde hace 23 años, vende productos de primera necesidad, en un inicio lo hizo de manera ambulante, hoy tiene un puesto de ventas en un mercado cerca de su casa. Su actividad empieza en las mañanas, atendiendo a sus clientes, y por las tardes, después de almuerzo, continua con su trabajo por algunas horas más. Siempre ofrece a su público consumidor productos de primera calidad, es por eso que acuden a su establecimiento, eso favorece mucho para su economía, ya que gracias a ella, puede sostener a su familia, así como también para aquellas dificultades financieras que se presenten en el futuro. Su deseo es seguir trabajando en su negocio, por lo querrá adquirir más mercadería. Este es su 13avo. Crédito con MFP,  por lo que asegura ser responsable con sus pagos, además manifiesta que dicho aporte le será  muy útil en el progreso de su negocio. Con el crédito que solicita, lo invertirá para comprar más productos variados para abastecer su tienda.
texts.en:
Antonia is 48 years old, the mother of three children, and lives in her own home. She has been selling basic necessities for 23 years. Originally she started out selling as a street merchant, but now she has a store near her home. She begins her work in the mornings, attending to her customers until lunchtime. In the afternoons, she continues her work for a few more hours. She always offers high quality products to the public, which is why people come to her establishment. Thanks to the favorable income that her business generates, she is able to support her family and handle any financial difficulties that may occur in the future. She wants to acquire more merchandise so that she can continue working in her business.

This is her thirteenth loan with MFP. Antonia assures us that she will be responsible with her payments. She also says the funds will be very useful in advancing her business. The loan will be used to buy various products to restock her store.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchadise for her store

loans.name: Honest Group

texts.en:
This group is named “Honest Group.” The members are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This will be their first Kiva loan through SMT.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods into their businesses, make more sales, and consequently improve their standard of living. They are, therefore, requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member of the group to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader is 26-year-old Fatmata S. (on the right in the photo) who sells market-food – pepper, salt, magi (used to give sauce a sweet taste, like boullion cubes), rice, sugar, etc. for four years. Fatmata intends to invest her share of the loan in her business by buying the above mentioned items in wholesale quantities. This entrepreneur was born in Makeni. She is married to a diamond miner and they have two children who attend primary school.

loans.use: Buy pepper, salt, magi, rice, sugar, etc. wholesale to add to her business

loans.name: Sokhna

texts.fr:
Madame Sokhna S. habite dans la localité de Ouakam. Elle a longtemps bénéficié du programme 
de  développement de l’enfant et de la famille. Elle est parent bénéficiaire a ce jour. Elle est mariée et mère de famille. Son mari est un polygame, retraité de la société air France. Par conséquent elle exerce une activité de commerce depuis 10ans pour soutenir sa famille et prendre en charge une partie des dépenses de la famille. Elle a déjà bénéficié de 3 prêts antérieurs. Madame S. s’active dans l’achat et la vente de pate d’arachide, d’huile de palme et de légumes. Elle a démarré ses activités  en allant au port autonome de Dakar pour acheter des produits saisonniers en provenance de la Casamance. Elle sollicite un crédit de 100 000 frs pour augmenter son stock de pate d’arachide et d’huile de palme, mais aussi dans le but de diversifier ses produits vendus en y intégrant du poisson séché et fume, du citron et autres.
texts.en:
Mrs. Sokhna S. lives in the village of Ouakam. She has benefited from the development program for children and the family for a long time, and she is to this day a parent and member of U-IMCEC (a Senegalese association of mutual savings and loans institutions). She is married and a mother. Her husband is polygamous and retired from Air France. Consequently she has been carrying out a business for the past ten years in order to support her family and cover part of the household expenses. She has already had three loans. Mrs. S. is active in purchasing and selling peanut butter, palm oil and vegetables. She began her business by going to the independent port of Dakar in order to buy seasonal products coming from Casamance. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 francs in order to increase her stock of peanut butter and palm oil, but also in order to diversify the range of products she sells by including dried and smoked fish, lemons and other products.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Increase of working capital

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Sale of food products and basic necessities

loans.name: Wan Word Group

texts.en:
Mariatu B. (on the right in the photo) is the leader of this group. She is a 39-year-old woman who lives in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone, with her husband and three children. Fatu has been selling fish, pepper, onions, magi (used to give sauce a sweet taste, like boullion cubes), tomatoes, etc. for many years now.  

She has requested a loan of SLL 500,000 from SMT, a Kiva field partner, to expand her business by buying fish, pepper, onions, magi and tomatoes in wholesale quantities to add to her current ones. This is the first loan that members of the "Wan Word" group have requested from SMT/Kiva lenders.

loans.use: Buy fish, pepper, onions, magi and tomatoes in wholesale quantities

loans.name: Gbombaya Group

texts.en:
Marie F. (on the right in the photo) is the leader of this group called "Gbombaya." She is a small-businesswoman. She sells gara lappers (locally dyed cloth), wool, rice etc. She is 40-year-old and married to a teacher. They have five children. Three of her children are in secondary school and two are in primary school. Like other mothers, she wants to give them a proper education and a bright future. She thanks God for her business because it helps provide for the increasing needs in her household. It is also a big help in sustaining her children’s education. 

Marie F. has applied for a loan of SLL 1,000,000 to expand her business. She will buy materials to make gara lapper like inks, caustic soda, powder and cotton. She will also buy bags of rice.

loans.use: To buy inks, caustic soda, powder, cotton, and bags of rice

loans.name: Turn-Table Group

texts.en:
This group is named “Turn-Table” after the location where these borrowers live. They are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This will be their first Kiva loan through SMT.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to add more goods, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. Therefore, they are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each group member to buy more goods to add to their inventory.

Their leader is 45-year-old Bai S. who is pictured on the right. Bai S. has been selling bowls for countless years now. He intends to use his share of the loan to expand his business by buying bowls at wholesale to add to his stock. In this way, Bai believes, he will be able to attract many more customers to his business.

loans.use: To buy bowls

loans.name: Llapanchis Tticarisunchis Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “LLAPANCHIS TTICARISUNCHIS” está representado por Julia que es la presidenta,  Olga  que es la secretaria, Zoraida que es la tesorera y Walter que es el fiscal. Los socios se reúnen cada treinta días en las oficinas de la unidad de micro finanzas de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad del Cusco. Actualmente, el banco comunal se encuentra en el VI ciclo y está conformado por 13 personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. 
 
Las actividades económicas de los algunos de los socios es por ejemplo; venta de comidas, venta pasamanería, venta de productos de belleza, venta de medicamentos, venta de ropa, venta brochetas, venta de panes y venta de verduras. Otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo de panadería, albañil, visitador médico y cajera.

Olga, tiene 32 años, es casada, tiene tres hijos y se dedica a la distribución de ropa, ella nos cuenta que viaja la ciudad de la Paz del país de Bolivia de donde trae su mercadería. Ya son 5 años que se dedica al negocio y le ha va muy bien gracias al empeño que le pone a su trabajo, ella requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio y desea comprar mercadería como por ejemplo casacas. Olga forma parte de la junta directiva del banco comunal desde el año 2008 y es la secretaria, ella fue elegida como una de las representes del banco comunal por su puntualidad y responsabilidad, 

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.

Cusco es una ciudad que se caracteriza por sus centros arqueológicos, su centro histórico,  sus paisajes, su historia, siendo una ciudad encantadora de la región sur del país.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Llapanchis Tticarisunchis” is led by Julia who serves as president, Olga who serves as secretary, Zoraida who serves as treasurer, and Walter who serves as auditor. The members meet every thirty days at the microfinance offices of Asociación Arariwa in the city of Cusco. The Communal Bank is currently in its sixth loan cycle and consists of 13 hardworking and enterprising individuals who look at each moment as an opportunity to get ahead and provide their children with a better future.

Some examples of the businesses the members are engaged in include selling food, decorations, beauty products, medicines, clothing, skewered meats, bread, and vegetables. Others work in service positions such as bakers, bricklayers, visiting health professionals, and cashiers.

Olga is 32 years old, married, has three children, and works as a clothing distributor. She tells us that she travels to the city of La Paz in Bolivia and brings back her merchandise. Olga has already been in this business for five years and has done very well as a result of her commitment to her work. She needs a loan to increase her business capital because she wants to buy merchandise, such as jackets. Olga has been a Communal Bank board member since 2008 and currently is the secretary. She was selected to be one of the Communal Bank representatives because of her punctuality and responsibility.

The members value and appreciate the loan that has been provided to them and promise to make their payments on time.

Cusco is a city known for its archaeological sites, historical center, landscapes, and history. It is a charming city located in the southern part of the country.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Operating capital to purchase merchandise

loans.name: One-Word Group

texts.en:
This group is named “One-Word Group”, a Krio phrase for unity. The members are all local entrepreneurs in Makeni, a city in northern Sierra Leone. This will be their first Kiva loan through SMT.  With the help of this loan, they will be able to buy more goods for their businesses, make more sales and consequently improve their standard of living. Therefore, they are requesting a loan of SLL 500,000 for each member of the group in order to buy more goods to add to their businesses.

Their leader, 37-year-old Isatu K. I. (pictured right) has been selling cooked rice for three years now. She will invest her share of the loan into her cooked rice business by buying cooking materials like rice, palm-oil, etc. at wholesale.  Isatu who was born in Sanda village, northern Sierra Leone is married and has four children who are attending secondary school.

loans.use: To buy cooking materials like rice, palm oil, etc.

loans.name: Musu

texts.en:
Musu K. dwells in a poor marginalised community by a river bank but yet refused to remain poor.  She started rearing pigs given to her by a friend.  She invested the proceeds obtained from the sale of the pigs into fuel/firewood.

She has been a group leader in ARD's Solidarity group lending scheme and has proven to be credit worthy.  As her business is becoming profitable, she now wants an individual loan that she will use to buy more fuel/wood and sticks in order to better serve the community in which she resides.

Musu intends to use the proceeds from the business to educate her three children.

loans.use: To buy wood and sticks

loans.name: Mbaye

texts.fr: Monsieur Mbaye N. est un homme de 46 ans qui habite dans la localité de  Ouakam depuis très longtemps. C’est un parent bénéficiaire marie qui évolue dans le secteur de transport. Il gère un taxi depuis 1988. Monsieur N. a choisi cette activité par le biais de son père qui était taximan. Il est marie et père de 5 enfants.  Il sollicite un crédit de 300 000frs destine a l’achat de matériel pour réfectionner son véhicule. Ce sont les revenus générés par son taxi qui lui permettent de supporter les charges de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mr. Mbaye Ndado is a 46-year old man who has been living in the town of Ouakam for many years. He is married and is providing for his children. He works in the transportation business. He has had a taxi since 1988. Mr. N. has chosen this activity motivated by his father, who was a taxi driver. He is married and the father of five children. He is seeking a loan of 300,000 West African francs in order to purchase materials for repairing his vehicle. The income that his taxi business brings allows him to support his family.

Translated from French by Ekaterina Sukhanova, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Vehicle repairs

loans.name: Tres De Mayo De Poroy Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “TRES DE MAYO DE POROY” está representado por la señora Vilma que es la presidenta, Yovanna que es la secretaria, Ana María que es la tesorera y Martha que es la fiscal. Los socios se reúnen cada treinta días en las oficinas de la unidad de micro finanzas de la Asociación Arariwa de la ciudad del Cusco. Actualmente, el banco comunal se encuentra en el IV ciclo y está conformado por 11 personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos. 
 
Las actividades económicas de algunos de los socios es por ejemplo; crianza y venta de ovejas, elaboración de artesanía, venta de frutas, compra y venta de animales menores, venta de verduras y menestras y venta de comestibles. Otros socios brindan servicios como por ejemplo; especialistas en nutrición, transportes, mecánico dental  y docencia.  

Cornelia, tiene 60 años, es madre soltera, tiene cinco hijos y se dedica a la venta de verduras en el mercado central de la ciudad del Cusco, ella nos cuenta que va al mercado aproximadamente a las 5 de la mañana y se queda vendiendo hasta las 6 de la noche. Ella requiere el préstamo que invertirá en comprar productos como por ejemplo machas, papas, huevera de pescado, etc. Ella vende sus productos por Semana Santa. Desde 1969 es vendedora en el mercado de San Pedro. Ya son 5 años que participa en el banco comunal y le va muy bien gracias a la puntualidad y responsabilidad de los pago de las cuotas. 

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.

Cusco es una ciudad que se caracteriza por sus centros arqueológicos, su centro histórico,  sus paisajes, su historia, siendo una ciudad encantadora de la región sur del país.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Tres de Mayo de Poroy” is led by Sra. Vilma who serves as president, Yovanna who serves as secretary, Ana María who serves as treasurer, and Martha who serves as auditor. The members meet every thirty days at the microfinance offices of Asociación Arariwa in the city of Cusco. The Communal Bank is currently in its fourth loan cycle and consists of 11 hardworking and enterprising individuals who look at each moment as an opportunity to get ahead and provide their children with a better future. Some examples of the businesses the members are engaged in include buying and selling sheep, producing handicrafts, selling fruit, buying and selling small animals, selling vegetables and stews, and selling groceries. Others work in service positions such as nutritionists, transport drivers, dental technicians, and teachers. Cornelia is 60 years old and a single mother of five children. She sells vegetables at the central market in Cusco. Cornelia says that she leaves for the market around 5am and stays until 6pm. She needs a loan to buy products such as clams, potatoes, fish eggs, and other items to sell for Holy Week. Cornelia has been a vendor at the San Pedro Market since 1969. She has participated in the Communal Bank for five years and has performed very well as a result of her timely and responsible payments. The members value and appreciate the loan that has been provided to them and promise to make their payments on time. Cusco is a city known for its archaeological sites, historical center, landscapes, and history. It is a charming city located in the southern part of the country.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase various food products to sell during Holy Week

loans.name: Pro Mujer Huayocari Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal “PRO- MUJER HUAYOCCARI” está representado por Soledad que es la presidente,  Celia que es la secretaria, Natalia que es la tesorera y Mauro que es el fiscal. Los socios se reúnen cada treinta días en la comunidad D. Huayocari del distrito D. Huayllbamba D. la provincia D. Urubamba del departamento del Cusco. Actualmente, el banco comunal se encuentra en el VII ciclo y está conformado por 12 personas trabajadoras y emprendedoras que buscan a cada momento las oportunidades para salir adelante y con su esfuerzo diario entregar un mejor futuro a sus hijos.

En la comunidad D. Huayocari los pobladores se dedican exclusivamente a la agricultura y ganadería, Huayocari es zona D. tierra fértil y forma parte del valle sagrado D. los Incas donD. se cultiva productos como por ejemplo maíz, zapallo, zanahoria y habas. Las actividades económicas D. algunos D. los socios es por ejemplo; venta D. verduras y maíz, venta D. hortalizas, crianza D. animales D. menores y venta D. flores. 

Aydee Florencia es casada, tiene tres hijos y su actividad principal es la venta D. hortalizas y flores y su actividad complementaria es la crianza D. animales menores, ella venD. en el mercado modelo D. la ciudad D. Urubamba las verduras. Ya son varios años que se dedica al negocio y le ha va muy bien gracias al empeño que pone a su trabajo, ella requiere el préstamo para aumentar el capital del negocio y desea comprar animales menores como por ejemplo cuyes.  

Los socios valoran y agradecen el préstamo otorgado mediante este medio y así mismo se comprometen a cumplir con el pago D. sus cuotas en el plazo establecido.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Pro-Mujer Huayocari” is led by Soledad who serves as president, Celia who serves as secretary, Natalia who serves as treasurer, and Mauro who serves as auditor. The members meet every thirty days at the microfinance offices of Asociación Arariwa in the city of Cusco. The Communal Bank is currently in its seventh loan cycle and consists of 12 hardworking and enterprising individuals who look at each moment as an opportunity to get ahead and proviD. their children with a better future.

In the community of Huayocari, the inhabitants engage exclusively in farming and raising livestock.
