Gloria recently successfully repaid a prior loan in the amount of 6,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to to purchase new items in order to expand her product offering. Gloria is now requesting another loan, this time in the amount of 8,000 PHP (though the total loan amount being sought by the group is 29,000 PHP, or $650), which will be used to purchase additional inventory and expand her working capital. Notably, this loan would be the third loan taken out by Gloria from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to further improve/expand her business.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches, which cover the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing additional inventory and by expanding her working capital

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet M. lives in the village of Poblacion 4 Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 32 years old, married and has two school-aged children. Juliet makes a living by running a bakery where she makes items such as bread to sell to people in her area. She has been in this business for more than ten years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Juliet joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC and is now applying for a new one for 20,000 PHP  She will use the additional revenue generated by her bakery to improve her family's living conditions. 

About GDMPC:
GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is made up mostly of farmers, fishermen and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her small bakery

loans.name: Eugenia

texts.en:
Eugenia A. lives in the village of Talakag Bukidnon. She is 50 years old, widowed and has one adult-aged child. She makes a living by providing video  and karaoke services to people in her community. She has been engaged in this business for more than three years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from her work.

In 2009, Eugenia joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her life and ability to engage in business. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from HSPFI, and is now applying for a new loan of 8,000 PHP to expand her small company. She plans to use the additional revenue made possible by this loan to continue expanding her business. 

About HSPFI:
HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and reaches out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to expand her business

loans.name: Erdene-Oyun

texts.en: Erdene-Oyun is 27 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live in a ger, a Mongolian nomadic tent. Her husband Chinbaatar works in a brick factory, and Erdene-Oyun makes a living by selling ice-cream and beverages at a local market. She is careful to keep her products in a freezer before selling them to her customers. She has been planning to buy a new freezer for her business, which has been in operation since 2008. Her profits are high, especially during the warm months. Erdene-Oyun is a very hard working woman who is skilled at what she does and has big plans for the future. She says, “I would like to expand my production line next autumn to sell more food products.”  She is requesting a 300,000 tugrug (~  $220) to buy a second freezer.

loans.use: To buy a second freezer for her small business

loans.name: Bano's Group

texts.en:
Bano is a wife of M. R. and lives in the city of Lahore in Pakistan. Lahore city is famous for its historical places and for its Punjabi foods. 

She is a 28-year-old woman who operates her own decorative-embroidery business. She receives orders from the cloth shops, and from the community as well. She also provides a facility for stitching to her customers. Her talent gives her a reward in the shape of money. She is also famous for her art in her community. Mostly ladies come to her to prepare embroidered dresses for marriage functions.
  
Bano is the mother of four children: one son and three daughters. All of her children are enrolled in a school and are getting an education. She has a dream to give her children a good education so they grow up with knowledge and improve their future. 

Her husband is involved in a dairy business. Currently, they have one dairy cow at their home. Bano has successfully repaid her three loans to Asasah (a microfinance institute in Pakistan and a Kiva partner). Now she is applying for a loan for the fourth time to purchase another dairy cow to expand her husband’s dairy business.

loans.use: To purchase another dairy cow for a dairy business

loans.name: Rosalie

texts.en: Rosalie D. is from the city of Dona Consuelo, Ozamiz City. She is 35 years old. Rosalie is married and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Rosalie provides welding services to local community members. Rosalie has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 10,000 Philippine pesos a month for these activities. In 2007, Rosalie joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Rosalie has successfully repaid a previous loan of 15,000 PHP from GDMPC, a Kiva partner. Rosalie is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This will be the seventh loan taken out by Rosalie from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. His oldest two daughters, ages 12 and 10, attend a local secondary school. They have been living together in their current home for five years. 

Baatarhuu operates a grocery store business in his town. He built his grocery store in August, 2009, in his yard and started operating his business in the same year. Baatarhuu has been successfully operating his business, and the business has been stabilizing. He has been planning to expand his grocery store into a supermarket in the future. 

Baatarhuu is a hardworking person. He is requesting a 1,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase more inventory for his grocery store.

loans.name: Nenita's Group

texts.en:
Nenita L. is a married, 39-year-old woman from the village of San Rafael. She has 3 school-age children. Nenita is the group leader of a 12-member loan group administered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if one of them is delinquent or defaults on a loan. The official name of this borrowing group is Nenita L.'s Group.

To earn a living, Nenita owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector. More specifically, she runs a general store, so her primary source of income is derived from selling a variety of products to her fellow community members. Nenita has been engaged in this business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.

In 2008, Nenita joined ASKI to gain access to financial services. In turn, she was able to engage in business activities and to thereby improve her standard of living. Nenita recently repaid a prior loan in the amount of 12,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase new items in order to expand her product offering. Nenita is now seeking another loan, this time in the amount of 15,000 PHP (though the amount being sought for the entire group loan is 165,000 PHP, or $3,700), which will be used to expand her business. This loan would be the fifth loan taken out by Nenita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business as a result of the loan to pay the tuition fees of her children.

About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches, which cover the Central and Northeastern areas of the country. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishermen/women, and entrepreneurs.

Nasanbat is a very hardworking person who has a great business mind. Besides his clothing trading business, he operates a taxi service as well. Nasanbat has many plans for the future and says, “My dream is one day to open brand clothing shop in the future.” 

He is requesting a 3,100,000 tugrug loan to purchase more clothing for his business.

loans.name: Ferma

texts.en:
Ferma B. is from the city of Maquilao, Tangub City. She is 54 years old. Ferma is married and has three adult children. To make a living, Ferma owns & operates a business raising "fish pond" fish for sale. Ferma has been engaged in her business for over 10 years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2008, Ferma joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ferma has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from GDMPC. Ferma is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be the third loan taken out by Ferma from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Linet

texts.en:
Linet is a widowed woman with two boys, who are aged 18 and five. Her younger son attends school and her older son is getting married and expecting a child. Linet sold charcoal for two years but had to stop because the prices rose too high.

To make a living, she worked at a company that exports clothes but she wants to use her ksh. 20,000 loan to buy charcoal and start her business again, selling from home to neighbors, hotels, kiosks and restaurants. Linet describes herself as hardworking and hopes to start another business selling cows (she already has one) and to build a house in the future. Recently, she broke her arm but she is excited that she will soon be a grandmother!

loans.use: To buy charcoal to sell

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena N. is from the village of Olango. She is 51 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Nena plants and harvests rice for sale. She has been engaged in her business for over 25 years and earns approximately $790 during harvest season.

In 2008, Nena joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 26,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Nena is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be her fifth loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to pay the tuition fees of her children. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a married woman with two sons and one daughter, who are 10, 8, and 6 years old. Her husband is a shopkeeper and tailor and her children attend school. Mary is also a tailor and wants to purchase materials and a sewing machine with the ksh. 40,000 loan. Additionally, she wants to buy flour, sugar, rice and cooking fat for her family's shop. She has been a tailor for 10 years and her customers are usually neighbors.

The months of January and June are her greatest challenge when there is little business. She also sells vegetables and cereals to make extra income. She rents her home and has no electricity or piped water. Mary hopes to purchase a lot on which to build her own house some day.

loans.use: To buy materials and a sewing machine

loans.name: Rosela

texts.en:
Rosela B. is from the village of Misom Baliangao, Misamis Occidental. She is 35 years old, married and has three school-aged children. To make a living, Rosela owns and operates a specialized retail store. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes from selling daily use products such as candies, biscuits, napkins, shampoo, soap, toothpaste, etc. in the local community. Rosela has been engaged in her business for over five years and earns approximately 7000 PHP a month from these activities.

In 2009, Rosela joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000 PHP from GDMPC which was used to to purchase additional inventory and working capital. Rosela is requesting a new loan of 7000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the second loan Rosela has taken out from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Renato

texts.en:
Renato D. C. is from the village of Olango. He is 45 years old, married, and has four school-aged children. To make a living, Renato plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over twenty years and earns approximately $1020 whenever he harvest his rice plants (palay).

In 2008, Renato joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. loans.name: Sophia

texts.en:
Sophia is a married woman with a son who is eight years old and attends school. She is a designer and wants to use the ksh. 30,000 loan to buy embroidery, materials, thread and a sewing machine. She has been in this business for four years and sells from home mainly to neighbors and friends.

She hopes to have a big business in town some day and to be able to purchase a house or plot in the future. Her greatest monthly expenses are electricity and food. Sophia describes herself as a young businesswoman who hopes to grow her business to help other people in the future.

loans.use: To buy embroidery, materials, thread and a sewing machine

loans.name: Warlito

texts.en:
Warlito A. is from the village of Olango. He is 45 years old. Warlito is married and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Warlito owns & operates an agriculture business, earning income from planting and harvesting rice for sale. Warlito has been engaged in his business for over 20 years and earns approximately 28000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Warlito joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Warlito has successfully repaid a previous loan of 30,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Warlito is requesting a new loan of 35000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Warlito from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to save as reserve funds for future emergencies. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizers such as manure.

loans.name: Mariam

texts.en:
Mariam is a married woman with two boys who attend school. She has been selling eggs wholesale to shops for the past year and wants to use the loan to purchase more eggs. Once a week, she buys 300 trays from farmers, who deliver them for free, and then sells about 50 trays per day. The main challenge to her business is that she struggles to have capital to purchase stock to meet the demand.

She currently rents her home and has electricity and water. Her greatest monthly expenses are school fees and rent. She hopes to expand her business and open a shop in the future. Mariam describes herself as very hard working.

loans.use: To buy eggs to sell

loans.name: Marvin

texts.en:
Marvin R. is from the village of Olango. He is 31 years old. Marvin is married and has 1 school child. To make a living, Marvin owns & operates a agriculture business venture in  planting and harvesting rice for sale. Marvin has been engaged in his business for over 9 years and earns approximately 45000 PHP per harvest.

In 2008, Marvin joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and to have the ability to engage in business activities. Marvin has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. Marvin is requesting a new loan of 31000 PHP which will again be used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. This will be the fifth loan taken out by Marvin from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Josephine is married to a pastor and has three sons and one daughter who are aged between 15 and 1. She is a tailor and wants to purchase a sewing machine with the ksh. 40,000 loan. She has a shop and mainly deals with her neighbors.

Her greatest challenge is that in January, when people have just paid school fees, her business is slow. She has been a tailor for six years and earns additional income by plaiting hair. She is planning on educating her children and expanding her business so that she can repay her loan. She owns her house but has no water or electricity. Food is Josephine's greatest monthly expense.

loans.use: To buy a sewing machine

loans.name: Malemin Group

texts.en:
Nazya is the group leader of the Malemin group. She lives in the 15th district, Kabul, Afghanistan. She is married and has four children. She is a tailor and works hard to earn money to meet her family’s requirements. She needs to buy a new sewing machine for her shop because she has lots of problems with the old one when sewing.

In addition, she wants to hire a student to support him through her business and to enlarge her business. He wants to take out an individual loan of 30,000 Afghani. She is very glad that she has the chance to progress.

loans.use: To buy a new sewing machine for her shop

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en: Virginia is 42 years old. She sells a variety of food which includes ham, hotdogs, sausages and, sometimes, dried fish. She currently has dried fish which she sells to her regular customers. She also sells ready-to-wear (RTW) clothes. Having a child who goes to college, she said that she has to work hard to keep up with the increasing school fees. She applied for a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to gain financial support for her business. She hopes to buy sausages, ham and more dried fish because these are what her customers look for.

loans.use: To buy dried fish, ham and sausages

loans.name: Pedrita

texts.en:
Pedrita owns a store and she sometimes sells at the elementary school in her barangay (village). She is 53 years old, married with three children. She has one child who is currently going to college. She and her husband work hard in order to sustain their child’s education. She also hopes to have a stable income.

In 2008, she joined CEVI hoping to gain access to its program. She says that its program is really helpful and she also likes the benefits she can get through insurance. She recently applied for a loan of 11,000 PHP, which she will use to buy stock, including boxes of Fern-C vitamins that she sells in her store.

loans.use: To buy additional inventory

loans.name: Arceli

texts.en:
Arceli, a 56-year-old rice farmer from Agusan Del Sur, is married to Ricarte and they have six children. Her oldest child is now 31 years old. She still has children who go to school. She and her husband work very hard to be able to provide for the family’s needs and sustain their children’s education.

She spends most of her time helping her husband maintain their farm. As they needed inputs for their rice farm, she applied to CEVI and asked to borrow 8,000 PHP. She will buy seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs that she needs.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Serfina Aoko

texts.en:
Serfina M. is 50 years old and from Manyatta in Kisumu. She is a widow with eight children, two of whom are boys and six are girls. Her first born is 30 years old and her last born is six years old. 

Serfina has a tree nursery that she has been running for the last five years. She is applying for her first loan from KADET after being introduced by another client who has previously benefited from their loans. She plans to use the money to buy different species of trees to add to her stock in the nursery.

She hopes to use the profits made to pay school fees for those of her children who are still in school and also to cater for the family's upkeep. Her desire is to purchase a piece of land and build a permanent house for her family so that they can have better shelter.

loans.use: To buy various species of trees for her nursery

loans.name: Rodolfo

texts.en:
Rodolfo R. is from the village of Olango. He is 40 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, he plants and harvests rice for sale. Rodolfo has been engaged in his business for over 15 years and earns approximately $760 a month for these activities.

In 2008, Rodolfo joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 25,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Alice Akinyi

texts.en:
Alice Akinyi is 37 years old and married to Peter Otieno. They have six children and they live in Manyatta area within Kisumu city. 

Alice has a stationery shop that she has been running for the past year. She is new to KADET after being introduced by a friend who is servicing loans with us and has seen their benefits. She intends to use the money to buy more stationery and add to her stock since many clients are in need of printing papers.

Her dream is to put a lot of effort into this business and see to it that it grows so as to enable her to cater for the family's needs and be able to put food on the table without much struggle.

loans.use: To increase her stock of printing papers

loans.name: Eunice Adhiambo

texts.en:
Eunice Adhiambo O. is 28 years old and lives in Nyamasaria in the outskirts of Kisumu city. She is a single mother of two children: Nicholas aged 13 and Everlyn aged 10. 

Eunice sells outfit materials/fabric and has been doing this for the past two years. She is applying for her first loan at KADET and intends to use the money to buy more materials to add to her fabric stock since they are on demand from her clients who consist of tailors around her neighborhood.

She hopes that her business will grow and enable her to earn enough profit so she can pay her children's school fees.

loans.use: To increase her stock of outfit materials

loans.name: Beatrice Awino

texts.en:
Beatrice Awino O. is 48 years old and from Riat area in Kisumu city. She is a single mother of three children: Cellestine aged 28, Stephen aged 24 and Victor aged two. 

Beatrice is a tailor and has been in this business for the past two years. She is known for making the latest designs in her neighborhood and this has attracted many clients to her. She is applying for her first loan at KADET after being introduced to us by a friend who is also our client. Beatrice is planning to use the money to buy more materials to add to her stock.

Her dream is to build a permanent house for her family and to work hard to ensure that her business expands so she can achieve this.

loans.use: To increase her stock of materials

loans.name: Bushenyi United Group

texts.en:
A determined and very ambitious lady, N. Catherine, aged 28 years, is a single mother with one child.

Catherine has operated a retail shop business for three years in Bushenyi town and at the end of every month is able to fetch a profit of 40,000 Ugandan shillings. Her main drawback has been having a small amount of stock in her business that cannot match the consumption rate of her customers.

Catherine is seeking a loan that can help her to stock more goods that will satisfy her customers’ high demand and also transform her business into a wholesale operation.

Being very committed to her business with good customer care, Catherine hopes to increase her sales revenue. This will bring about a fundamental change in her business and enable her to achieve a self-sustaining life and cater for her family requirements.

loans.use: To purchase more stock for her store

loans.name: Nolito

texts.en:
Nolito T. is from the village of Olango. He is 48 years old, married, and has 5 school-aged children. To make a living, Nolito plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 18 years and earns approximately $1050 per harvest.

loans.name: Succès Plus Group

texts.en:
Germaine B. is 41 years old, married and has two children aged 13 and 16. She joined one of Hope’s groups named “Succès Plus” (a DRCongo microfinance program) in April 2009 and is the leader of that group which consists of 38 members. Thanks to Hope’s loans, the group members’ businesses have prospered.

Germaine has been active in her business since 1982. She runs a sewing workshop and sells sewing accessories to the east of Kinshasa. She is dedicated to her business which generates a profit of $200 per month. Her business is the only source of income which she has to support her family. Germaine has already received and successfully repaid four loans. She is planning with the coming loan to purchase sewing accessories of good quality that are needed by her clients in order to generate more profit. Her dream is to open a sewing center in her locality.

loans.use: To increase her stock of sewing accessories

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Rachid

texts.en:
Rachid is a 52-year-old married man who has three school-age children. He owns a carpentry shop in his town and has been involved in this occupation for the past 30 years. He supplies doors and windows and makes all designs requested by clients. He has a heavy demand for his services due to the good reputation and experience he has made during this long period of business. 

Today, Rachid is asking to borrow $1,200 to purchase more wood and accessories to be ready before the summer season. It is common for people to make repairs to their homes during summer and he needs to be prepared.

loans.use: To purchase more wood and accessories

loans.name: Teodora

texts.en:
Teodora A. is from the village of Tipolo, Plaridel, Misamis Occidental. She is 81 years old, a widow and has six adult children. To make a living, Teodora is engaged in the agriculture sector, primarily in rice production. She has been engaged in her business for over 45 years with a monthly net income of 2,500 PHP. She is also a pensioner receiving a monthly pension of 1,500 PHP.

She joined PMPC to gain access for financial support for her business. This is the seventh loan which Teodora has requested from PMPC. She is requesting 20,000 PHP which will be used for her medical bills.

About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in north-western Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. 

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay her medical bills

loans.name: Nanziga Kwagalana Group Of  Mpigi

texts.en:
It goes without saying that Samali K. is a 38-year-old self-assured and high-spirited mother of four.  She has a well-rounded experience of ten years in pig husbandry and agricultural produce sales.

In Nanzoga, Mpigi, Samali has established a business niche for herself on the basis of her down-the-line hard-work spirit.  She has had financial difficulties in her piggery business before but, given her beaten-track experience, she has managed to nip them in the bud earlier.

In the same breath, what has also made Samali’s produce sales business successful is the fact that she has always owed it to herself to provide the best possible quality produce for her clients.  At present, she makes monthly profits to the tune of 200,000 shillings. With these combined businesses, she has consolidated her profits and, as a result, all her children are in school.

With this loan, Samali wants to herald a new chapter in her business by buying more surplus crops like maize and cabbages. She also wants to ring substantial changes in her pig-husbandry business, which means buying more pigs that she will be able to sell to her increasing client base.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs and crops like maize, cabbages and peas

loans.name: Arnolio

texts.en:
Arnolio C. is from the village of Olango. He is 35 years old, married, and has 2 school-aged children. To make a living, Arnolio plants and harvests rice for sale. He has been engaged in his business for over 13 years and earns approximately $980 every harvest season.

In 2008, Arnolio joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve his living situation and ability to engage in business activities. He has successfully repaid a previous loan of 28,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase fertilizers such as manure. 

Arnolio is requesting a new loan of 30,000 PHP which again will be used to purchase fertilizers. This will be his 5th loan from ASKI. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of his family. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers such as manure

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell.

loans.name: Teresita

texts.en:
Teresita S. is from the village of Brgy. Roxas, Solano, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 49 years-old and married with three school-aged children. To make a living, Teresita owns and operates a business cultivating fruit trees and harvesting their fruit for sale. Teresita has been engaged in her business for over seven years and earns approximately 3,000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Teresita joined Kiva partner ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Teresita has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops to raise. Teresita is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to pay for services to increase crop yield. This loan will be the sixth loan taken out by Teresita from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fishers and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield.

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
Daniel is 41 years old, married to Lucy Njeri and they have three school-going children. He runs a cleaning and upholstery business in Naivasha town and this business is three years old. It has been very profitable and he has seen a potential for growth. 

He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He had earlier taken out a loan of Kshs 30,000 which he repaid well and on time. He plans to buy a vacuum cleaner and buffing machine to make his work easier.

As demand for his services grow, he plans to employ other people to help him with the work in the near future.

loans.use: To buy a vacuum cleaner and a buffing machine

loans.name: Kayed

texts.en:
Kayed is a 59-year-old married man and the father of six children, four of whom are employed and help him in the household. He runs a successful taxi business in his home town. He is an experienced driver who has been working for over 22 years.

With the requested Kiva loan of $1,000, Kayed will be able to purchase a new car instead of the used one so that he can continue to expand his business and offer a good transportation service to customers. He feels positive about his business growth for the coming year.

loans.use: To purchase a new car

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria sells goats. She has been in this business for 10 years and she like the business. She is very hardworking and she makes sure she has food on the table everyday through her hard work. She is requesting a loan of NGN 120,000 to purchase more goats to sell and better meet her customer demands. She is 55 years-old and married with eight children.  She lives in Benin City with her family. She says thanks to all Kiva lenders for their financial assistance.

loans.use: To purchase goats.

loans.name: Ben

texts.en:
Ben is still new in his retail business as he has run his shop for only seven months. He takes care of his four-year-old son after separating from his wife.

Ben was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan. He wants to boost his business and that is the reason he has applied for this loan. He will buy dry foodstuffs in bulk to stock his shop. This will include maize and wheat flour, sugar, rice and cooking fat.

Ben hopes to grow his business and even move to wholesale one day.

loans.use: To buy dry foodstuffs in bulk

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter has run his food stall in Naivasha for the last three years. He is married to Monicah Akai and they have six school-going children.

Peter was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his first loan which he plans to use to buy supplies for his food kiosk which includes, flour, sugar and cooking fat.

Peter hopes to grow his food kiosk in future, have a loyal customer base, and turn it into a more profitable operation.

loans.use: To buy cooking fat, flour and sugar in bulk

loans.name: Elijah

texts.en:
Elijah has been in the auto repair business for the last eight years. He was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his second loan. He repaid his first loan very well which he used to buy a welding machine. He plans to use the proceeds from this loan to buy a new paint-spraying machine for use at his garage.

Elijah hopes to grow in the auto repair business and become a mechanic of choice in Naivasha town.

loans.use: To buy a paint-spraying machine

loans.name: James

texts.en:
James has been supplying fuel and paraffin in Naivasha town for the last five years. His target market is the low income earners within Naivasha town. He is 22 years old, married to Ruth Nyawira, and they have a nine-month-old baby. He also has a secondary business where he carries people and goods on his motorbike and thus improving on his income base.

James was introduced to KADET by his friend and this will be his third loan, having repaid the previous two loans well and on time. He plans to add to his stock of fuel and paraffin (kerosene) for selling in his shop.

In future, James plans to diversify and venture into the transport business owning a fleet of Matatus (Minivans) which will operate on the Nairobi - Naivasha route.

loans.use: To add to his stock of fuel and parrafin in his shop

loans.name: Janet Kadzo

texts.en:
Janet is a 37-year-old lady married to Anderson with whom she has two children, Ian and Pauline.

Janet is in the tailoring business making all types of clothes. She started this business three years ago and it earns her a monthly profit of Ksh 15,000. Her customers are residents of Malindi town. Janet also works as a housekeeper and this is her secondary income source.

Janet was introduced to KADET by a friend and she got more encouragement to join from her mother. She has applied for a loan which she plans to use to buy tailoring materials worth Ksh 8,500 and pay for transport with Ksh 1,500. With the extra earnings from this loan she plans to expand her business and save for her children's education.

Janet is a hardworking and visionary woman who hopes to settle at her own place and own a big business.

loans.use: To buy materials and pay for transport

loans.name: Nizar

texts.en:
Nizar is a 29-year-old engaged man living with his parents. He's an experienced hairdresser, having ten years of experience. In 2003, he opened his own barber shop in his hometown. This man caters to a wide range of clientele in the village and its neighborhoods.

Today, Nizar wishes to improve the decor of his barbershop and buy a new desk. He will also increase his merchandise such as shampoos, gels, sprays, etc. In order to do so, he is requesting a $1,200 loan.

Nizar is certain that, with the help of the loan, his business productivity will be increased and he will be able to collect more savings for his wedding.

loans.use: To improve the decor of his barbershop, buy a new desk, and increase his merchandise

loans.name: Mukama Mwesiga Group Of Kampala

texts.en:
In business, first impressions mean everything. That is one adage that never slips K. Flora’s mind. In her seven years doing business, this mother of two has been brought to terms with this fact. Her commitment, friendly nature and hard work have brought her dividends in her tailoring business in Nankulabye, Kampala.

K. Flora is a 36-year-old happily-married go-getter businesswoman. Her business, since its inception, has steadily been bringing her profits to the tune of 70,000 weekly. With this loan she is gleefully upbeat that her business will gain further ground. By and large, she intends to buy more sewing machines.

loans.use: To buy new sewing machines

loans.name: Kadzo Pola

texts.en:
Kadzo Pola is a 41-year-old woman married to Kazungu with whom she has eight children: five girls and three boys.

Kadzo has been practicing farming for the last four years and earns a monthly profit of Ksh 2,000 from the sale of her farm produce. Her customers are the local residents of Malindi.

Kadzo, who is on her second loan, learned about KADET through a chief’s baraza (a meeting organized by the area chief and KADET officer). She will utilize this loan to buy a cow with Ksh 8,000 and buy seeds with Ksh 2,000. With the extra earnings from this loan she will pay school fees for her children.

A hardworking woman, Kadzo hopes to improve her residential house and build rental units on her plot.

loans.use: To buy a cow and seeds

loans.name: Katwekamwe, Rukungiri Group

texts.en:
K. Getrude, aged 57, is hardworking and dedicated to her banana plantation enterprise that she has run for over ten years. This has earned her a monthly profit of 150,000 Ugandan shillings that has helped in providing basic needs for her children with some side income generated from selling clothes.

This loan will be an incentive for Getrude to purchase farm tools like hoes and fertilizer and to modernize her plantation to improve on the banana crop which is commonly used for making a local dish by customers. This will increase Getrude’s sales revenue and enable her to pay her daily bills including her children’s school bills.

Getrude belongs to a group of nine members who hold each other accountable and insure one another in paying back the loan.

loans.use: To purchase farm tools like hoes, manure and mulches

loans.name: 070905-Hoằng Hoá, Thanh Hoá Group

texts.en: Khuyên Lê Thị (709051) is a 35-year-old female living in the town of Hoằng Hoá, Thanh Hoá. She is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is 07.09.05- Hoằng T.nh- Hoằng Hoá- Thanh Hoá (07.09.05). Khuyên is married and has two school-aged children. She owns and operates a business raising pigs for sale. She has been engaged in this business for over ten years and earns approximately 1,500,000 VND a month. In 2007, Khuyên joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 3,079,800 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Khuyên is now requesting a new loan of 5,000,000 VND which will again be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. The loan will be her 4th from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income. About the other borrowers in the group: 1. Lê Thị Dung (709052) is a 48-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. 2. Lê Thị Hương (709053) is a 46-year-old female who is requesting a 5,000,000 VND loan to support her business raising livestock. About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: The mission of Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainable financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders. ***************************************************** Khuyên Lê Thị (709051) là 35 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy sống ở Hoằng Hoá - Thanh Hoá. Khuyên là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 4 các thành viên. Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ.. Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 07.09.05- Hoằng T.nh- Hoằng Hoá- Thanh Hoá (07.09.05). Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi heo để bán. Khuyên thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 10 năm. Từ các hoạt động này, Khuyên kiếm được khoảng 1500000 VND. Vào 2007, Khuyên đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải thiện sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy. Khuyên đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 3,079,800 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng mua gia súc còn nhỏ để nuôi & bán sau này. Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 5,000,000 VND. Khoản vay sẽ là 4th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm: 1. Lê Thị Dung (709052) là 48 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. 2. Lê Thị Hương (709053) là 46 tuổi nữ. Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 5000000 VND. Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp. Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc. Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women: Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ vì Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa. *Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. . Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Josephine Karembo

texts.en:
Josephine is a 35-year-old woman married to Lazarus who is a teacher. Together they have three children aged between five and 12 years. They live in the Gongoni area in Malindi where Josephine runs a tailoring school. She has been in the tailoring business for the last fifteen years and earns a monthly profit of Ksh 8,500. She also practices farming on the side.

Josephine was introduced to KADET by an existing member and has borrowed from the teachers’ SACCO (another micro-finance institute) before and is now on her second loan with KADET. She has applied for a loan of which she will utilize Ksh 30,000 to prepare her land and plant seedlings, buy a sewing machine worth Kshs 7,000, and pay for transport and miscellaneous expenses with Ksh 3,000.

With the extra earnings from this loan Josephine plans to expand her tailoring school and advertise it. Her dream is to see the tailoring school expand and improve the lives of her students.

loans.use: To pay for land preparation and plant seedlings, buy a sewing machine, and pay transport costs

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase used clothes.

loans.name: Khadije

texts.en:
Khadije, a 45-year-old married woman, owns a bakery in her hometown. A mother of three, she opened this small business to help her husband with the family's income and to pay for their children's schooling.

Khadije produces all types of Lebanese traditional breads. She has a great demand for her food products and her freshly prepared goods are enjoyed by members of her village and neighboring towns. 

Today, Khadije is requesting to borrow $1,200 to invest in buying a new oven because she is planning to continue expansion of her business and she is positive about the coming year.

loans.use: To buy a new oven

loans.name: Mbayang

texts.fr: Mbayang N. est âgée de 55 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 07 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KEUR NGALGOU depuis 05 ans et a 10 fois de suite été bénéficiaire de crédit. Elle fait un petit commerce de sucre et développe parallèlement une embouche ovine. son nouveau prêt lui permettra de faire la promotion de son projet. Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Mbayang N. is a 55 year old married mother of seven who has been a member of hte Keur Ngalgou microfinance association for five years, and has received 10 consecutive loans. She has a small sugar business and is setting up a sheep rearing business, and this new loan would enable her to promote her project effectively. Her ultimate goal is to look after her family's needs. .

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her business

loans.name: Nada

texts.en:
Nada is a 43-year-old married woman and mother of three dependent children.

Nada has run a tailoring business from her home for over twenty-five years and she has been able, during this period, to support her husband with the family income. She offers all sewing services in addition to a clothes repair service.

Nada has already taken advantage of her first loan from Kiva and she's very pleased with her decision to take a loan from Ameen because she was able to expand her business. She's a very punctual client who has repaid her loan on time.

Today, Nada is asking for a new loan of $1,200 to buy more textiles to satisfy the demands of her customers.

loans.use: To buy more textiles

loans.name: Badamsuren

texts.en:
Badamsuren is 33 years old and lives with her two daughters in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a rented house and yard. Her daughters, ages 8 and 6, attend a local secondary school.

Badamsuren has been successfully running a grocery store since 2008. She made a contract to rent the house where she is now living with her two daughters and has operated her grocery store for five years. As the business is the only financial support for her family she has many responsibilities, including finding money to pay for the university fees of her daughters and to expand her business.

Badamsuren is a very hardworking person who is both a good businesswoman and a mother. She says, “Since I started operating my business, I have become a more experienced trader. I would like to purchase this grocery store when the five-year rental period is finished.”

Badamsuren is requesting a 3,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of food products and fruit at wholesales prices to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase food products for her store

loans.name: Nana

texts.en:
Nana M. prepares Fante kenkey for distribution to her customers at Akotokyire who then resell it in smaller quantities. Fante kenkey is a type of kenkey found mostly in the Central and western Regions of the country, specifically the Fante’s area.

Nana has been through senior high school. She is married and has two children and supports her husband in taking care of the family. Her loan will be used to buy additional bags of maize to prepare Fante kenkey to be able to distribute more to her increasing customers. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to re invest into her business.

To prepare her kenkey she buys maize from the market, soaks it in enough water to soften the maize. She washes it on the third day and sends it to the mill to be milled. She then makes a mixture of dough out of the milled wet corn and leaves it for the next day.

She divides the dough into two, uses one for her firm half-cooked dough (mixes it with water to get it into a porridge form and cooks it for some time to get a firm mixture or texture to the dough) and mixes the rest of the uncooked dough with the half-cooked dough.

She moulds the result into balls and wraps them in plantain leaves that have been dried. She then cooks them again till they becomes soft to eat.

Kenkey can be eaten with various kinds of sauces such as pepper sauce, with fried or roasted fish, roasted chicken, roasted turkey or any other kind of meat or fish.

loans.use: To buy additional bags of maize for preparing Fante kenkey

loans.name: Tungalag

texts.en:
Tungalag is 39 years old and lives with her husband and two children in Hovd province, Mongolia. She and her family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. One of her children is a university student and the other is a secondary school student.

Tungalag operates a beauty products trading business. Since 2009, she has been working as a salesperson at a shop called S-3, and earns 200,000 tugrugs (approximately 145 USD) per month. This is in addition to the income she earns from her beauty products trading business, which she runs from the same shop.

Tungalag currently stocks 2,500,000 tugrugs (approximately 1795 USD) worth of products. Her product selection is very good and she has a great business mind.

Tungalag is requesting a 500,000 tugrugs loan to purchase additional beauty products and pajamas to sell to her many customers.

loans.use: To additional beauty products and pajamas

loans.name: Alice

texts.en:
Alice K. is married to a policeman and has two children. She has received junior high education. She helps her husband in taking good care of her family.

Alice sells secondhand clothing, moving from house to house at Akotokyire. She has been selling secondhand clothes for about two years now. Her loan will be added to her initial capital so she can buy in larger quantity (in bales) for resale.

Alice hopes to use the new earnings from her business to save to reinvest back into her business.

loans.use: To add to her initial capital so she can buy in bales

loans.name: Nurbol

texts.en:
Nurbol is 29 years old and lives with his wife and son in Bayan-Ulgiy province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent. His 5-year-old son attends a local kindergarten.

Nurbol operates a clothing trading business in his town. He purchases his products in the Chinese border towns of Ereen and Uremj. He has been operating his business since 2005, and has gained much experience. He has two sales channels at the local Tirlik market, and a loyal customer base.

With his earnings, Nurbol has been providing money for his family expenses and expanding his business. He is an honest person and his family is very important to him. He says, “I have been planning to save for my child's education fees starting now.”

Nurbol is requesting a 4,000,000 tugrug loan to purchase a large amount of clothing in Uremj to resell for a profit.

loans.use: To purchase a large amount of clothing in Uremj

loans.name: Kakra

texts.en:
Kakra A. sells slippers, moving from one house to the other in and around Akotokyire. With the income she generates from the sale of slippers, Kakra is able to support her husband to pay for rent and food for the home.

Kakra’s loan will be used to buy other types of slippers to add to the types she currently sells. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to buy a shop.

Kakra has no formal educational background. Her husband is a driver.

loans.use: To buy other types of slippers

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad is a 32-year-old married man with two young children. In 2008, he started his own business – he opened a water delivery company in his town. He's very famous in his town and known by his good reputation.

Jihad was able, since then, to have a good number of clients and has found an opportunity to expand his business into other areas. He cooperates with his wife who works as a home-based hairdresser to support the family expenses.

Today, Jihad is asking to borrow $1,200 to purchase water coolers for his project. He's planning to repay his loan early and to take a new loan in the future.

loans.use: To purchase water coolers

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi de l’association Allachon est composé 8 de femmes   mariées de la ville de San région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 42 ans et au moins 6 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage et parenté.
Depuis environ 20 ans ces femmes du groupe Benkadi font la vente de condiments, d’encens et de produits cosmétiques.
Parmi ces femmes se trouve une,  qui est très sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité de son encens,  Hawa Mallé alias ‘’éternelle beauté’’. 
Hawa s’approvisionne à Bamako et compte acheter, 3 kg de magnokisseni, 12 bouteilles de parfums différents et 1kg de djekalani. Elle mélange tous ces ingrédients en un jour et la ferme pendant une semaine. La semaine suivante elle procède à la mise en  embouteille pour les vendre à une  clientèle composée essentiellement de femmes et certain homme qui achète  pour leurs femmes. Madame Hawa vend en espèce et  quelques fois à crédit. 
Elle espère réaliser 25.000FCFA de bénéfice par mois et les autres membres du groupe envisagent avoir 21.000FCFA de bénéfice. Ces bénéfices leurs  permettrons de rembourser leurs prêts et subvenir aux dépenses familiales.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group, part of the Allachon microcredit association, is made up of 8 married women from the San region of Ségou, the fourth largest region in the Republic of Mali. They live as part of traditional families and are of an average age of 42 with at least 6 children each. They met through neighbourly and parental links. The Benkadi group have sold condiments, incense and cosmetics for the past twenty years. There is one lady within the group that is very sought after for the quality of her incense; Hawa Mallé, aka 'eternal beauty'. Hawa sources her goods from Bamako and intends to buy 3kg of 'magnokisseni' (an incense ingredient), 12 bottles of different fragrances and 1kg of 'djekalani' (another incense ingredient). She combines these three ingredients on the same day and lets the mixture rest for a week. The following week she bottles the mixture and sells it to a customer base made up of women and men buying it for their wives. Mrs Hawa takes cash, and occasionally credit, sales. She hopes to generate a 25,000 FCFA profit every month, and the other group members envisage generating profits of 21,000 FCFA. These profits will enable them to repay their loans and meet their family's needs.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing ingredients for the production of incense

loans.name: Gade

texts.fr: Gade K. est une femme de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Depuis 5 ans elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KEUR NGALGOU et y a bénéficié successivement de 10 crédits qu'elle a toujours bien gérés et remboursés à temps. Elle développe un petit commerce de sucre et de riz et fait parallèlement de l'embouche ovine. Ses bénéfices lui servent à participer financièrement aux différentes charges familiales et à subvenir à ses besoins personnels.
texts.en:
Gade K. is a 48-year old woman who is married and mother to six children. For the past five years she has been a member of the Banc Villageois in KEUR NGALGOU and has benefited from ten consecutive loans, all of which she has managed well and repaid on time. She is building up a small business selling sugar and rice and at the same time has a sheep fattening activity. Her profits allow her to contribute financially to the various family expenses and to provide for her personal needs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To finance her project and develop her small business

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en:
Ekua K. is a widow who has four children. She has not received any form of education.

Ekua sells maize and soap at Akotokyire. The photo was taken in her house where she had less stock of maize and soap to show since her stock was at the market.

Ekua uses her income in taking care of herself and her children. She will use the loan to purchase more bags of maize and soap for resale.

With the new profits from her extended business, Ekua plans to save to educate her children.

loans.use: To purchase more bags of maize and soap to sell

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkadi de l’association Badenya est composé de 9 femmes mariées de la ville de Tominian, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Les membres du groupe Benkadi qui ont en moyenne 36 ans et 4 enfants, vivent dans des grandes familles traditionnelles élargies et se sont connues à travers le voisinage, la  parenté. 
Elles exercent presque la même activité, à savoir la vente d’articles divers tels les condiments alimentaires, créneau de Angèle D..
Angèle D. s’est spécialisée dans la vente de condiments de toutes sortes.
Afin de satisfaire le besoin de sa clientèle  qui ne cesse d’augmenter, elle a trouvé une solution, en intégrant l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso. Elle s’approvisionne en gros à San pour revendre en détail à Tominian 
Angèle compte utiliser son prêt pour  acheter, 50 paquets de maggi,  12 sacs de sel de cuisine, 30 boîtes de concentrées de tomate, 2 paquets de poivres, 20 kg de l’ail. 
Elle réalise 12.500FCFA de bénéfice par mois qui sera utilisé pour agrandir son entreprise. 
 NB : Fatoumata D. est absente de la photo pour raison d’accouchement.
texts.en:
The Benkadi group, which belongs to the Badenya association, is made up of nine married woman from the town of Tominian, in Ségou, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. The members of the Benkadi group, who average 36 years of age and have an average of four children each, live in large extended traditional families and met each other through neighbors and relatives. They carry out more or less the same activity, that is the sale of a variety of products such as food condiments, the niche of Angelle D.. The latter is, notably, specialised in the sale of all sorts of condiments. She found a solution to satisfy customer needs which are constantly increasing, by joining the microfinance institution, Soro Yiriwaso. She gets her supplies wholesale in San to resell on a retail basis in Tominian. Angelle plans to use her loan to buy 50 packs of Maggi stock cubes, 12 bags of kitchen salt, 30 boxes of tomato concentrate, two packets of pepper and 20kg of garlic. She makes 12,500 FCFA of profit a month which will be used to expand her business. N.B. Fatoumata D. is absent from the photo above as she was giving birth.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of condiments

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi B. lives with her husband and her three children and supports her husband in the general welfare of the family. She has received junior high education.

Esi sells onions at Akotokyire which she has been doing for some time now. Her loan will be used to buy more onions to sell. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to buy a shop for her business.

loans.use: To buy more onions to sell

loans.name: Maty

texts.fr: Maty N. est âgée de 43 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 08 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KEUR NGALGOU depuis 7 ans et demi d'où elle a bénéficié de 15 crédits qui lui permettent jusqu'à aujourd'hui de développer son activité d'embouche bovine. Elle va acheter du foin et une paire de bœufs les engraisser puis les vendre au bout de 4 à 5 mois. Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge familiale.
texts.en:
Maty N. is 43 years old, married and mother to eight children, who are all in her care. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in KEUR NGALGOU for seven and a half years and has had 15 loans, which have allowed her to develop her sheep fattening business up until the present time. She is going to buy hay and a pair of oxen which she will fatten up and sell after four to five months. Her objective is to help out her husband with the family responsibilities.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of a pair of oxen to fatten up

loans.name: Nakyanakumbi F Kigongo Rose Group

texts.en: K. Rose is a hardworking business woman of fifty years old, the mother of two children, of whom one child is still going to school. She is carrying out a tailoring business of which she has stayed in for over three years. She is using the loan to purchase material and cloth for making different designs for her customers. She is trying hard to make the best designs for the customers to win their attention. She is a hardworking business woman whose dreams are struggling for the welfare of her family and educating her child who is still in school.

loans.use: To purchase material and cloth for making different designs for her customers.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Benkadi de l’association Kotognogotala est un regroupement de 7  femmes   mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 38 ans et au moins 7 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de  voisinage et  de parenté.
Depuis environ 10 ans, ces femmes du groupe Benkadi font la vente de riz,  de condiments alimentaires, du  bois de chauffe etc, et parmi elles se trouve une, à savoir Madame Astan Maïga, qui est  très sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité du riz qu’elle offre. 
Elle s’approvisionne  sur place à San en gros et envisage acheter, 7 tonnes de riz qui seront revendus à San en demi gros et en détail à une clientèle constituée d’hommes et des femmes, en espèce et à crédit. 
 Tandis que Astan Maïga (qui ravitaille presque tous les policiers de la ville de San en riz) espère obtenir un bénéfice mensuel de 42.000FCFA  les autres membres envisagent  avoir un bénéfice de 36.000FCFA, qui serviront à rembourser le prêt et subvenir aux besoins familiaux.
texts.en:
Benkadi Group, belonging to the Kotognogotala association, is a grouping of seven married women from the town of San, in Ségou, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families, average 38 years of age and have at least seven children. They got to know each other through neighbors and relatives. For around ten years these women in the Benkadi group have been selling rice, food condiments, firewood etc.. Among them is one Astan Maïga, who is in great demand from her customers for the quality of the rice that she sells. She gets her supplies locally in San on a wholesale basis, and is planning to buy seven tons of rice which will be resold in San, partly wholsesale as well as retail to a customer base made up of men and women, for cash and on credit. While Astan Mäiga (who supplies rice to nearly all the policemen in San) hopes to make a monthly profit of 42,000FCFA, the other members of the group estimate that they will make a profit of 36,000FCFA, which will be used to repay their loan and provide for family needs.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rice

loans.name: Purevdorj

texts.en:
Purevdorj is 46 years old and lives with his wife and three children in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. He and his family live together in a ger, the Mongolian nomadic tent. Two of his children, ages 15 and 13, attend a local secondary school.  His eldest child, Ganchodor, will graduate from high school in 2010. 

Purevdorj operates two businesses. During the summer, he sells souvenirs with his wife near local monuments. They have been selling souvenirs since 2003. The province they live in is a center of tourism in Mongolia, which is a great advantage to their business. During the winter, Purevdorj works as a solderer and electrician. Purevdorj is certified as an electrician, and has worked as a plumber at a local generator plant for many years (1981-2000).  He is an industrious person who has a great business mind. His family is the most important thing for him and he says, “As a father, I would like to be financially available to provide a good education and other necessary expenses for my children until they grow up.” He is requesting a loan to purchase souvenirs and religious articles in the Chinese border cities of Ereen and Beejin.

loans.use: To purchase more souvenirs

loans.name: Benkan Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Benkan de l’association Balemayaton est composé 4 de femmes   mariées de la ville de San, région de Ségou, quatrième  région administrative de la république du Mali. Elles  vivent dans des familles traditionnelles et ont en moyenne 31 ans et au moins 3 enfants. Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage. 
Depuis environ 6 ans, ces femmes du groupe Benkan  font la vente  de riz, de pâte d’arachide, de poissons, de savons, de sucre, etc, et  parmi elles  se trouve une qui est très sollicitée par ses clients pour la qualité de sa  marchandise, la présidente du groupe Fanta S. qui excelle dans l’achat vente de la pâte d’arachide. 
Les femmes du groupe Benkan collaborent avec Soro Yiriwaso depuis maintenant une année afin de développer  leurs activités et  satisfaire le besoin des clients. 
Madame Fanta S. s’approvisionne à San, en gros, auprès des sœurs catholiques qui produisent de la pâte d’arachide, pour revendre en détail et en espèce aux femmes de son quartier. 
Elle  compte acheter, 50 seaux de 5kg qui généreront un bénéfice  de 28.000 FCFA et les autres membres prétendent avoir un bénéfice de 22 000FCFA par mois. 
C’est avec ce profit que ces femmes envisagent rembourser le prêt et réinvestir dans leurs activités.
texts.en:
The Benkan group, belonging to the Balemayaton association, is made up of four married women from the town of San in Ségou, the fourth administrative region of the Republic of Mali. They live in traditional families, average 31 years of age and have at least three children. They got to know each other through neighbors. For around six years these women in the Benkan group have been selling rice, peanut butter, fish, soaps, sugar, etc. Among them there is one woman who is in great demand for the quality of her goods; she is the president of the group, Fanta S., and she excels in the purchase and sale of peanut butter. The women in the Benkan group have been working with Soro Yiriwaso for a year now with the aim of building up their businesses and satisfying their customers' needs. Mrs. Fanta S. gets her supplies wholesale in San, from Catholic nuns who produce peanut butter, and she sells them retail and for cash to women in her neighborhood. She is planning to buy 50 5kg buckets of peanut butter which will generate a profit of 28,000FCFA, and the other members of the group claim to be making a monthly profit of 22,000FCFA. With these profits the women plan to repay their loan and reinvest in their businesses.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of peanut butter

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua B. is divorced and has five dependents. She has a junior high school education. Ekua goes to Techiman in the Brong Ahafo Region to buy plantain, pear or avocado, cassava, banana and other food in bulk to sell at Akotokyire. Ekua uses the income she acquires from the sale of the food to educate, clothe and feed her dependents. Ekua will use the loan to purchase additional food to be able to supply most of the market women living within her area. With the new income from her expanded business, Ekua plans to save to reinvest into her business.

loans.use: To purchase additional food to supply most of the market women living within her area

loans.name: Thieb

texts.fr: Thieb D. est âgée de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 07 enfants en charge. Elle est depuis 3 ans et demi membre du Banc Villageois de KEUR NGALGOU, elle y a été 7 fois de suite bénéficiaire de crédit. Elle fait de l'embouche bovine, avec son nouveau prêt elle va acheter un bœuf pour l'engraisser et le revendre au bout de 4 à 5 mois au niveau des marchés hebdomadaire de sa localité. Son objectif est de participer à la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Thieb D. is 48 years old, married and mother to seven children, who are in her care. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in KEUR NGALGOU for the past three and a half years and she has had seven consecutive loans. She has a beef fattening activity, and with her new loan she is going to buy an ox to fatten up and resell after four to five months at the weekly markets in her town. Her aim is to contribute to supporting her family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Develop and promote her beef fattening activity

loans.name: Fatou

texts.fr: Fatou D. est une femme de 48 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants en charge. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de KEUR NGALGOU depuis 6 ans et y a eu 12 bonnes expériences avec le crédit. Elle fait de l'embouche ovine, elle va acheter 10 moutons, les engraisser pendant 5 mois et ensuite les vendre au niveau des marchés hebdomadaires de sa localité. Son objectif est de soutenir son mari dans la prise en charge de sa famille.
texts.en:
Fatou D. is a 48-year old woman who is married and and mother to six children, who are in her care. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in KEUR NGALGOU for the past six years and has had a good experience with the 12 loans she has taken out. She has a sheep fattening business and she is going to buy ten sheep, fatten them up for five months and then sell them at the weekly markets in her town. Her aim is to support her husband in providing for their family.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ten sheep for fattening

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Preparation and sale of "bouillie" made from corn and millet

loans.name: Ekua

texts.en: Ekua E. operates a fufu joint at Akotokyire where she pounds fufu with a variety of soups, depending on the day of the week. On this day, Monday, she was going to serve the fufu with palm nut soup. Fufu is one the most popular food in the country. It is made out of cassava and plantain, cassava and cocoyam or yam mixed together in a form of pounding. Ekua has received a senior high education.  She is married to a driver and has two children. Ekua helps her husband in the upkeep of the home. Her loan will be used to buy more foodstuffs such as yam to cook to bring variety into her sales. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save to put up a shop where people can comfortably sit to eat.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs such as yam

loans.name: Oyuntuya

texts.en: Oyuntuya is 65 years old and lives with her grandson in an apartment the Baganuur district of Ulaanbaatar, the largest and capital city of Mongolia. Oyuntuya earns her living by selling clothing and underwear at a counter. She sells a variety of clothing, including men's and women's trainers, underwear, and woolen sweaters to sell to her many customers. Oyuntuya has been operating her business since 2003, and has steadily expanded it since then. She has gained a great deal of business experience over the past seven years. With her earnings, she purchased a car for her eldest son. Oyuntuya is an honest person. She says, “University tuition fees are very high now. Therefore, I have to expand my business and increase my profit in order to help my grandson attend the university.” She is requesting a loan to increase her working capital.

loans.use: To increase working capital

loans.name: Saye

texts.fr: Saye N. est âgée de 50 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 06 enfants. Elle est depuis 3 ans et demi membre du Banc Villageois de KEUR NGALGOU et y a reçu 7 fois de suite de crédit et n'a jamais eu de problème de remboursement. Elle fait de l'embouche bovine et son nouveau prêt lui permettra d'acheter un bœuf, de l'engraisser et de le revendre au niveau des marchés hebdomadaire de sa localité. Elle participe à l'amélioration des conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Saye N. is 50 years old, married and mother to six children. She has been a member of the Banc Villageois in KEUR NGALGOU for three and a half years and has had seven consecutive loans; she has never had any problems with the repayments. She has a beef fattening activity, and her new loan will allow her to buy an ox, fatten it up and resell it at the weekly markets in her town. She is contributing to the improvement in her family's living conditions.

Translated from French by Alison Le Bras, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To develop her livestock selling activity

loans.name: Hedar Homa Group

texts.en:
Najiba is the group leader of H. Homa group. She lives in district 15th of Kabul Afghanistan. She wants to take a loan for her husband’s business. He has a general store, and all the family members benefit from his income. He needs to rent another shop which is located next to his previous shop and buy more supplies for it, and besides, he wants to expand his business and to attract more clients, so he has requested an individual loan of 15000 Afghani.

He is happy that he has got the chance to progress as soon as possible.

loans.use: He wants to expand his business

loans.name: Enhtaivan
